zDkLZSYo.title: Formation and characterization of PrGa0.9Mg0.1O3 synthesized by a citric acid method
zDkLZSYo.abstract: PrGa 0.9 Mg 0.1 O 3 was synthesized by using a citric acid method. Compared with the sample prepared by the solid state technique, the sample synthesized by the citric acid method crystallized at a lower temperature. X-ray diffraction data indicated that a pure orthorhombic phase was formed at 1300 °C. PrGa 0.9 Mg 0.1 O 3 showed a conductivity of 0.076 S/cm at 800 °C and an activation energy of 32.98 kJ/mol. Its average thermal expansion coefficient from 600 to 1000 °C was 11.9 × 10 −6 K −1 , which well matches with the NiO/YSZ anode and doped LaMnO 3 cathode. A power density of 55 mW/cm 2 and a short circuit current density of 200 mA/cm 2 were obtained at 900 °C in a single fuel cell experiment by using PrGa 0.9 Mg 0.1 O 3 as an electrolyte. This could be attributed to the existence of hole conduction in the sample. Keywords Oxides Chemical synthesis Thermogravimetric analysis Electron microscopy 1 Introduction The solid oxide fuel cell (SOFC) attracts much attention because of its high efficiency and low pollution. Stablized ZrO 2 is widely used as the electrolyte of SOFCs [1] , however, limited by its oxygen ion conductivity, zirconia-based SOFCs must operate at 1000 °C, which causes some electrode reactions and other problems. Reduction of the operating temperature can increase the stability, prolong the lifetime and lower the cost of SOFCs. Therefore, searching for new electrolyte materials with high conductivity at lower temperatures is worthwhile. Several years ago, LaGaO 3 -based oxides with high oxygen conductivity were found by Ishihara et al. [2] . These ABO 3 -type perovskites can accommodate large concentrations of anion vacancies and show a superior oxygen ion conductivity [3–7] , e.g., La 0.8 Sr 0.2 Ga 0.83 Mg 0.17 O 2.825 has the conductivity of 0.17 S/cm at 800 °C [3] , which is the highest oxygen ion conductivity of any ceramic apart from the Bi 2 O 3 based materials. In materials prepared by traditional solid state technique, a little glass phase exists in the grain boundary region, which assists in forming denser microstructure, but decreases the oxygen ion conductivity [8] . On the contrary, the citric acid method starts from a mixed solution of different components, so it becomes an attractive route to synthesize materials with high purity, ultrahomogeneity, and a reduced crystallizing temperature. In the family of ABO 3 -type rare gallate perovskites, PrGaO 3 -based oxides have also been suitable as electrolytes of SOFC [9] . In our previous work [10] , we found PrGa 0.9 Mg 0.1 O 3 electrolyte had superior properties. To obtain a sample with better properties, we synthesized PrGa 0.9 Mg 0.1 O 3 perovskite by using a citric acid method. The sample was characterized by thermal analysis, X-ray diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), density and dilatometer. Its electrical properties were also studied. 2 Experimental 2.1 Sample synthesis According to the formula PrGa 0.9 Mg 0.1 O 3 , the required amount of Pr 6 O 11 was first dissolved by nitric acid, then mixed with stoichiometric amounts of Mg(NO 3 ) 2 ·6H 2 O and Ga(NO 3 ) 3 in distilled water to form a solution with a concentration of 0.05 mol/l. After that, citric acid was added to the solution in the molar ratio 1:1 to the cations. The solution was then stirred, heated at 60 °C until a gel was formed. The resulted gel was evaporated in an oven at 150 °C for 6 h to yield dry powder. Finally, it was pelletized and sintered at 1500 °C for 12 h. 2.2 Thermal analysis Differential thermal analysis (DTA) and thermal gravity analysis (TGA) data of the resulted gel were obtained from a Perkin-Elmer DTA 1700 and TGA 7 thermal analyzer in air. The data were collected from room temperature to 1000 °C for DTA and 800 °C for TGA at a rate of 10 °C/min. 2.3 X-ray diffraction The structure of the sample was examined by X-ray diffraction using a Rigaku-D-Max rA 12 kW X-ray Diffractometer with Cu K α radiation ( λ = 0.15418 nm). 2.4 Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM) The particle size of the powder calcined at 400 °C for 2 h, and the morphology of the sample sintered at 1500 °C for 12 h were observed by a Hitachi H8100-IV microscope. 2.5 Density The density of the sample sintered at 1500 °C for 12 h was measured using the Archimedes technique. 2.6 Thermal expansion property A Netzsch DIL 402C/3/G dilatometer was used to measure the thermal expansion properties of the sample from room temperature to 1000 °C in air at a rate of 5 °C/min. 2.7 Electrical properties A Solartron SI-1260 Impedance Analyzer was applied to measure the conductivity of the sample, which was painted with silver paste on both sides and baked at 850 °C for 15 min. A single fuel cell was fabricated by using a sample disc (0.8 mm in thickness and 10 mm in diameter) as the electrolyte and silver as the cathode and anode. The performance of the cell was measured at 900 °C. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Thermal analysis Fig. 1 shows the DTA and TGA data of the gel. There exists a strong exothermal peak at 227 °C in the DTA curve, which suggests the decomposition of the residual organic matter. The exothermal peak at 288 °C can be attributed to the decomposition of the nitrates. Both have corresponding weight loss reflected in the TGA curve. The weight loss starts from about 100 °C, at which point the absorbed water evaporates. A wide, weak exothermal peak at about 650 °C can be attributed to the crystallization and no corresponding weight loss shows in the TGA curve, consistent with the following XRD data. 3.2 XRD patterns The XRD data of the samples sintered at different temperatures are shown in Fig. 2 . After being sintered at 600 °C in air for 12 h, the powder remains amorphous. It has crystallized at 700 °C and some unknown phase, Pr 6 O 11 and a perovskite phase are formed. It indicates that the exothermal peak at 650 °C in the DTA curve is due to the crystallization of the sample. When the sintering temperature is above 800 °C, PrGa 0.9 Mg 0.1 O 3 perovskite with orthorhombic structure dominates in the sample. The impurity phase disappears when the sintering temperature is further increased to 1300 °C. Fig. 3 shows the XRD patterns of the samples synthesized by using the citric acid method and the solid state technique. It is clear that the sample using citric acid method crystallized at lower temperature. 3.3 TEM, SEM results and density The TEM micrograph of the powder sintered at 400 °C for 2 h is shown in Fig. 4 . The average particle size is about 200 nm. Fig. 5 shows the morphology of the disc sintered at 1500 °C for 12 h. It can be seen that the sample disc is dense except for some small pores. The density of disc sintered at 1500 °C is 6.92 g/cm 3 , which is about 95.7% of the theoretical density (7.23 g/cm 3 ) derived from XRD data. Both results show that the sintering of sample is good. 3.4 Thermal expansion property The thermal expansion property of PrGa 0.9 Mg 0.1 O 3 and YSZ is shown in Fig. 6 . The average thermal expansion coefficient of PrGa 0.9 Mg 0.1 O 3 from 600 to 1000 °C is 11.9 × 10 −6 K −1 , which is equal to that of a (∼35 vol.% NiO)/YSZ anode. Above 30 vol.% nickel, the conductivity of NiO/YSZ anode is about three orders of magnitude higher than that of the anode with nickel below 30 vol.% [1] . The thermal expansion coefficient of the anode also increases with the content of NiO. Compared with YSZ, whose thermal expansion coefficient is about 10.5 × 10 −6 K −1 , the PrGa 0.9 Mg 0.1 O 3 electrolyte can be better matched with the NiO/YSZ anode at the operating temperature of SOFCs. Furthermore, the PrGa 0.9 Mg 0.1 O 3 electrolyte matches with a doped LaMnO 3 cathode in thermal expansion coefficient as well, e.g., the thermal expansion coefficient of La 0.89 Sr 0.10 MnO 3 is 12.0 × 10 −6 K −1 [1] . 3.5 Electrical properties Fig. 7 shows the Arrhenius plot of the PrGa 0.9 Mg 0.1 O 3 electrolyte. Its conductivity is 0.076 S/cm at 800 °C and the activation energy is 32.98 kJ/mol. The I – V and I – P curves of a single fuel cell using PrGa 0.9 Mg 0.1 O 3 as the electrolyte are shown in Fig. 8 . A power density of 55 mW/cm 2 and a short circuit current density of 200 mA/cm 2 are obtained at 900 °C. The low performance is due to the existence of Pr 4+ ions in the sample, which results in hole conduction [9] . When doping the divalent ion Mg 2+ for the trivalent ion Ga 3+ , the tetravalent praseodymium, Pr 4+ , is created besides oxygen vacancies, as stated in our previous work [11] . In the sample with small particle size, because of its high reactive activity, there exists a higher Pr 4+ content, which decreases the open circuit voltage and power density of the cell. 4 Conclusions The PrGa 0.9 Mg 0.1 O 3 electrolyte with orthorhombic structure was synthesized by a citric acid method. The average particle size of the powder sintered at 400 °C for 2 h is about 200 nm. The pure perovskite phase was formed at 1300 °C. The sample was dense after being sintered at 1500 °C for 12h, and also matched with NiO/YSZ anode and doped LaMnO 3 cathode in thermal expansion coefficient well. Nevertheless, the performance of the single fuel cell using PrGa 0.9 Mg 0.1 O 3 as an electrolyte was low because of the hole conduction in the sample. Further work needs to be done to solve the problem. 9xJPz9E4.title: A Ni/YSZ composite containing Ce0.9Ca0.1O 2-δ particles as an anode for SOFCs
9xJPz9E4.abstract: A composite material (hereafter referred to as NYC) containing Ni, Y 2O3-stabilized ZrO2 (YSZ) and Ce 0.9Ca0.1O2-δ (CC10) particles was prepared and used as the anode of solid oxide fuel cells (SOFCs). The performance of NYC was better than that of conventional Ni/YSZ anodes in terms of anodic overpotential and interface impedance. The additional CC10 particles improved the anode properties. XRD results suggest that a solid solution of YSZ and CC10 was produced. From impedance measurements, it is concluded that the solid solution exhibits substantial electronic conduction. Ni/YSZ/15 wt% Ce 0.9Ca0.1O2-δ anodes exhibited the best properties over the experimental temperature range. A SOFC with an anode of Ni/YSZ/15 wt% Ce0.9Ca0.1O2-δ provided the maximum power density and current density. Addition of CC10 with an average particle size of 0.3 μm was more advantageous than that with an average size of 3 μm. © 2003 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

iASXez8Q.title: A screen-printed Ce0.8Sm0.2O1.9 film solid oxide fuel cell with a Ba0.5Sr0.5Co0.8Fe0.2O3-δ cathode
iASXez8Q.abstract: Screen-printing technology was developed to fabricate Ce 0.8 Sm 0.2 O 1.9 (SDC) electrolyte films onto porous NiO–SDC green anode substrates. After sintering at 1400 °C for 4 h, a gas-tight SDC film with a thickness of 12 μm was obtained. A novel cathode material of Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 Co 0.8 Fe 0.2 O 3− δ was subsequently applied onto the sintered SDC electrolyte film also by screen-printing and sintered at 970 °C for 3 h to get a single cell. A fuel cell of Ni–SDC/SDC (12 μm)/Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 Co 0.8 Fe 0.2 O 3− δ provides the maximum power densities of 1280, 1080, 670, 370, 180 and 73 mW cm −2 at 650, 600, 555, 505, 455 and 405 °C, respectively, using hydrogen as fuel and stationary air as oxidant. When dry methane was used as fuel, the maximum power densities are 876, 568, 346 and 114 mW cm −2 at 650, 600, 555 and 505 °C, respectively. The present fuel cell shows excellent performance at lowered temperatures. Keywords Solid oxide fuel cells Screen-printing Electrolyte films Ce 0.8 Sm 0.2 O 1.9 Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 Co 0.8 Fe 0.2 O 3− δ 1 Introduction Solid oxide fuel cells (SOFCs) have attracted more and more attention in recent decades because of their high energy conversion efficiency, flexibility of fuels and reduced pollution [1,2] . The traditional Yttria-stabilized zirconia (YSZ)-supported SOFCs always operates at around 1000 °C for acceptable performance. However, it is difficult to expect a good long-term stability at such a high temperature because of the sintering of the electrodes, the diffusion of material between the cell components and the mismatch of the thermal expansion coefficients (TEC) [3] . From the viewpoint of cost reduction and long-term stability, it is necessary to lower the operating temperature. Anode-supported YSZ thin film SOFCs have been extensively studied and have shown excellent performance at intermediate-temperatures from 600 to 800 °C [4–6] . Substituting doped-cerias for YSZ will further lower the operating temperature because of the higher ionic conductivity of doped-cerias at the lowered temperature [7] . Leng et al. [8] reported that dense Ce 0.8 Gd 0.2 O 1.9 (GDC) electrolyte films could be obtained in situ by a solid-state reaction. A maximum power density of 578 mW cm −2 at 600 °C was obtained based on a 10-μm-thick GDC film and a La 0.8 Sr 0.2 Co 0.2 Fe 0.8 O 3 (LSCF)–GDC cathode. Xia and Liu [9] prepared a 20-μm-thick GDC film by conventional dry-pressing and got a maximum power density of 400 mW cm −2 at 600 °C by using Sm 0.5 Sr 0.5 CoO 3 (SSC)–SDC as the cathode. It is known that the performance of anode-supported film SOFCs is basically limited by cathode polarization resistance [9,10] . So, a new cathode material is desirable to further improve the performance. Recently, Shao and Haile [11] reported that Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 Co 0.8 Fe 0.2 O 3− δ (BSCF) was an excellent cathode material for SOFCs operating at lowered temperatures. Their single fuel cell made of a dry-pressed SDC electrolyte film (20 μm thick) and a BSCF cathode layer exhibited a very high power density of 1010 mW cm −2 at 600 °C using moist hydrogen as fuel and airflow as the oxidant. Screen-printing [12,13] is a simple and inexpensive technology for fabrication of dense films onto porous substrates. Peng et al. [14] fabricated a dense Ce 0.8 Y 0.2 O 1.9 (YDC) film (15 μm thick) onto a porous NiO–YDC anode by screen-printing. Based on this YDC film and Sm 0.5 Sr 0.5 CoO 3 cathode, they obtained a maximum power density of 230 mW cm −2 at 600 °C. Xia et al. [15] got a Ce 0.8 Sm 0.2 O 1.9 (SDC) electrolyte film with a thickness of 30 μm using a similar screen-printing technology. Combined with a SSC–SDC cathode, their fuel cell provided maximum power densities of 118 and 397 mW cm −2 at 500 and 600 °C, respectively. In this paper, gas-tight Ce 0.8 Sm 0.2 O 1.9 films were fabricated on porous NiO–SDC anode substrates by screen-printing. Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 Co 0.8 Fe 0.2 O 3− δ powder was prepared and screen-printed onto the sintered SDC electrolyte films. Using hydrogen as fuel and ambient air as oxidant, a single cell with a 12-μm-thick SDC film exhibited maximum power densities of 1080 and 1280 mW cm −2 at 600 and 650 °C, respectively. The excellent fuel cell performance shows a significant improvement when the fabrication of the ceria-based electrolyte film for SOFCs uses screen-printing technology. 2 Experimental NiO powder was prepared by a precipitation method. Ammonia (analytical reagent, A.R.) was added to a Ni(NO 3 ) 2 ·6H 2 O (A.R.) solution drop by drop to obtain nickel hydroxide deposition. Then, the as-prepared deposition was aged at 70 °C for 40 min. After washing by alcohol and drying at 105 °C, the resultant deposition was finally fired at 400 °C for 2 h to get nickel oxide powder. Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 Co 0.8 Fe 0.2 O 3− δ powder was synthesized by a citric-nitrate process. Ba(NO 3 ) 2 (A.R.), Sr(NO 3 ) 2 (A.R.), Co(NO 3 ) 2 ·6H 2 O (A.R.) and Fe(NO 3 ) 3 ·9H 2 O (A.R.) were used as the starting materials. Stoichiometric amounts of nitrate were dissolved in deionized water and citric acid (A.R.) was added as a complexant. The molar ratio of the total cation concentration to the citric acid was 1:1.15. The solution was evaporated at 75–100 °C to form a dry gel, which was finally fired at 1000 °C for 6 h to get Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 Co 0.8 Fe 0.2 O 3− δ powder. SDC (Sm 0.2 Ce 0.8 O 1.9 ) powder was also prepared by the citric-nitrate process. Stoichiometric amounts of Ce(NO 3 ) 3 ·6H 2 O (A.R.) and Sm 2 O 3 (A.R.) were dissolved in diluted HNO 3 (A.R.) and citric acid (A.R.) was added as the complexant. The solution was evaporated and dried to form dry gel. The SDC powder was obtained by firing the dry gel at 750 °C for 2 h. The as-prepared powder of NiO and SDC was mixed in a weight ratio of 65:35 and ball-milled for 10 h using ethanol as media. To form sufficient porosity in the anode, 15 wt.% starch was added as the pore former. The mixed powders were pressed into pellets of 13 mm in diameter and 0.5 mm in thickness. The green pellets were pre-sintered at 1000 °C for 2 h to strengthen their mechanical property. The sintered pellets were used as the support for the fuel cells. The SDC ink for printing was made of SDC powder (55 wt.%) and ethyl cellulose-terpineol vehicle (45 wt.%). The SDC ink was screen-printed onto the pre-sintered NiO–SDC anode substrates through a Terylene screen. The mesh count of the screen is 165 wires cm −1 and the wire diameter is 30 μm. The screen has an opening size of 30 μm and an open area of 25%. Three printing passes were needed to get an adequate thickness. After drying in air for 10 h, the anode-supported SDC electrolyte films were sintered at 1400 °C for 4 h at a heating rate of 5 °C min −1 . The Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 Co 0.8 Fe 0.2 O 3− δ cathode was also screen-printed onto the sintered SDC films and fired at 970 °C for 3 h. X-ray diffraction (Bede D 1 X-ray diffraction meter) was used to confirm the crystalline structure of the prepared powders. The microstructure and morphology of the screen-printed SDC films were examined by a scanning electron microscope (SEM). The cell performances were measured using a SI 1260 impedance/gain-phase analyzer in combination with an SI1287 electrochemical interface (Solartron Instruments, Hampshire, UK). A four-probe configuration was adopted in the electrochemical testing. Hydrogen (100 ml min −1 ) and dry methane (60 ml min −1 ) was used as fuel, respectively, while the ambient air was used as oxidant. 3 Results and discussion As shown in Fig. 1 , the as-prepared powder of NiO shows the expected phase structure without impurity phases. The X-ray pattern for Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 Co 0.8 Fe 0.2 O 3− δ matches well with the diffraction data for a perovskite phase while the pattern for Sm 0.2 Ce 0.8 O 1.9 shows the standard cubic fluorite structure. Fig. 2 shows the cross-sectional microstructure of a single cell and the surface of a screen-printed SDC film. As can be seen from Fig. 2 a, the SDC film adheres well to both the Ni–SDC anode substrate and the Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 Co 0.8 Fe 0.2 O 3− δ cathode. The SDC film is 12 μm thick with somewhat closed pinholes in cross-section. From Fig. 2 b, the SDC thin films are composed of grains of irregular shapes without obvious cracks or pinholes. Fig. 3 shows the performance of the single cell with a 12-μm-thick SDC film from 405 to 650 °C. When hydrogen (100 ml min −1 ) was used as fuel and ambient air as oxidant, the maximum power densities were 1280, 1080, 670, 370, 180 and 73 mW cm −2 at 650, 600, 555, 505, 455 and 405 °C, respectively. It is gratifying that the performance of the present cell at 600 °C is as high as that obtained with the state-of-the-art anode-supported YSZ film of SOFCs at 750–800 °C. Fig. 4 shows a comparison of the maximum power density between the present cell and prior reports. It can be seen that the present cell can provide the highest power density among the cells listed in Fig. 4 . Since the cells have similar structures, similar ceria-based electrolyte films and comparable film thickness, the distinct difference in power density can be ascribed to the cathode used. The present cell exhibits the highest power density, which implies that Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 Co 0.8 Fe 0.2 O 3− δ possesses a better cathode performance at lower temperature than that for Sm 0.5 Sr 0.5 CoO 3 and La 0.8 Sr 0.2 Co 0.2 Fe 0.8 O 3 [11] . Fig. 5 shows the cell performance from 505 to 650 °C using dry methane as fuel and ambient air as oxidant. The maximum power densities were 876, 568, 346 and 114 mW cm −2 at 650, 600, 555 and 505 °C, respectively. Xia et al. [15] operated a screen-printed SDC film (30 μm thick) SOFCs using moist methane as fuel and obtained the maximum power density of 304 mW cm −2 at 600 °C. This value is obviously lower than our result. 4 Conclusion A 12-μm-thick Ce 0.8 Sm 0.2 O 1.9 electrolyte film was successfully fabricated onto an anode substrate by screen-printing technology. Combined with a novel Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 Co 0.8 Fe 0.2 O 3− δ cathode, a single cell of Ni–SDC/SDC (12 μm)/Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 Co 0.8 Fe 0.2 O 3− δ provided a maximum power density of 1080 mW cm −2 at 600 °C, using hydrogen as fuel and stationary air as oxidant. When dry methane was used as the fuel, the maximum power densities were 876 and 568 mW cm −2 at 650 and 600 °C, respectively. The power densities reported in this paper are obviously higher than prior reports on screen-printed doped-ceria film SOFCs. This initial cell performance indicates that, with an optimized cathode material, it is a realistic goal to fabricate a high performance SDC film SOFC capable of operating at low temperature using a low-cost screen-printing technology. Detailed investigations related to the fuel cell impedance, electrode polarization and long-term stability will be carried out in the near future. Acknowledgment Financial support from the National Natural Science Foundation of China (grant no. 10504005) is gratefully acknowledged. References [1] N.Q. Minh J. Am. Ceram. Herzhof D. Sebold F. Tietz J. Power Sources 141 2005 216 226 [5] R. Zheng X.M. Zhou S.R. Wang T.L. Wen C.X. Ding J. Power Sources 140 2005 217 225 [6] Y.J. Leng S.H. Chan K.A. Khor S.P. Jiang Int. J. KFIysCDK.title: Performances of Ba0.5Sr0.5Co0.6Fe0.4O3-δ-Ce0.8Sm0.2O1.9 composite cathode materials for IT-SOFC
KFIysCDK.abstract: Composite materials Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 Co 0.6 Fe 0.4 O 3− δ (BSCF4)–Ce 0.8 Sm 0.2 O 1.9 (SDC) (BSCF4–SDC) were prepared and characterized as cathode for intermediate temperature SOFC (IT-SOFC). The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), thermal expansion coefficient (TEC), electrical conductivity and electrochemical property measurement were employed to study the materials. The XRD result proved the reaction between BSCF4 and SDC in BSCF4–SDC. The conductivity of BSCF4–SDC was higher than that of BSCF4; in additions the thermal expansion coefficient of the BSCF4–SDC was about 18% lower than BSCF4 from 30 to 800 °C in air. Polarization curves and impedance spectra measured at intermediate temperatures showed the BSCF4–SDC electrode yielded lower resistance values than that of BSCF4 electrode. And the addition of 30 wt% SDC to BSCF4 had the best electrochemical properties; e.g., polarization resistance of BSCF4–SDC30 was 0.298 Ω cm 2 at 550 °C, which was nearly 85% lower than that of BSCF electrode. Keywords X-ray diffraction Ionic conduction Electronic transport Thermal analysis 1 Introduction High operating temperature of SOFC result in high cost and materials compatibility challenges, so low down the operating temperature of SOFC is the most important issue to settle for its practical use [1,2] . It has been found that, during intermediate temperature, the performance of cathode tends to limit the cell's performance. Thus, optimization of cathode material and performance is essential [3–7] . The Co-based pervoskite oxides are good candidates for IT-SOFC because of their high conductivity and good electrochemistry performance. Particular those substituted with Sr and Fe on A and B site, respectively, designated generically as LSCF, are known to show suitable stability ranges, and to possess good performance in air at intermediate temperatures [8] . To improve the performance of LSCF further, Perry Murray et al. added Ce 0.8 Gd 0.2 O 3 (GDC) to LSCF obtained LSCF-GDC, and succeeded [9] . Then, recently, Shao and Halle [10] presented Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 Co 0.8 Fe 0.2 O 3− δ (BSCF) as a new cathode material for reduced-temperature SOFC operation, which demonstrated excellent performance in both dual-chamber and single-chamber configurations at temperatures lower than 600 °C. The high power output of BSCF cathode resulted from the high rate of oxygen diffusion through the material, and this material was first developed as a high-temperature (>800 °C) oxygen permeation material. Unlike typical cathode, the A-site cations of BSCF perovskite are all alkaline earth species rather than rare earth and an alkaline earth element [11,12] . Although the performance of BSCF is good, there are still some problems in use for IT-SOFC cathode. First, Similar to other Co-based materials, the thermal expansion coefficient (TEC) of BSCF is extraordinary high, with the value of about 19.7 × 10 −6 K −1 in air from 50 to 900 °C [13] . So the mismatch of thermal expansion coefficient between the BSCF cathode and Ce 0.8 Sm 0.2 O 1.9 (SDC) electrolyte make it hard to attach the cathode to electrolyte. Second, the electrical conductivity of BSCF is lower than the commonly used cathode, which may influence the electrochemical performance. Against this background, composite of BSCF-SDC are studied roundly focusing on the key properties, such as minish the problem of thermal expansion mismatch, improve the adhesion of the electrode to the electrolytes, as well as enhance the electrical conductivity. In this paper, the Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 Co 0.6 Fe 0.4 O 3− δ (BSCF4) cathode was modified by incorporating an amount of SDC to get a series of composite materials BSCF4–SDC. Then the composite materials were investigated in comparison with pure BSCF4 on electrical conductivity and thermal expansion coefficient, as well as electrochemical properties toward SDC electrolyte. 2 Experimental 2.1 Material preparation Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 Co 0.6 Fe 0.4 O 3− δ (BSCF4) powders were synthesized by sol–gel method. The appropriate metal nitrates were dissolved in water, and a combination of EDTA and citric acid served as complexing agents. Mild heating induced gelation of solution, and the resulting gel was held at 200 °C for several hours to remove organics. And then the primary powders were calcined at 950 °C for 5 h [10–14] . The composite materials BSCF4–SDC prepared by incorporating SDC into BSCF4, milled with an agate mortar for 1h, were identified by the weight of added SDC (10, 20, 30 and 40 wt%), noted as BSCF4–SDC_ x ( x = 10, 20, 30, 40). X-ray (Bede Scientific, D 1 X-ray diffractometer, UK, Cu Kα radiation, λ = 0.15418 nm; operated at 40 kV, 45 mA;) diffraction analysis was employed to identify materials’ crystal structure, the 2 θ – θ scans were carried out from 20° to 80° with a step of 0.02° and a scan speed of 1.2° min −1 . The thermal expansion measurements (pressed bar 6.00 mm in diameter and about 6.70 mm in length, sintered at 1100 °C for 4 h) were conducted with a Netzsch DIL 402C/3/G dilatometer, using fused silica sample holder, from 30 to 800 °C (operated in air, heating rate: 5 K min −1 , air purge, flow rate: 50 ml min −1 ). Uniaxially pressed pellets of SDC (13 mm in diameter; 0.5 mm in thickness) powders was calcined at 1150 °C for 5 h. To improve the adhesion of interface, the surface of SDC pellet was coarsened by spraying a SDC layer then sintered at 1400 °C for 5 h in air. The powder mixture BSCF4–SDC dispersed in terpineol was spread on the coarsened electrolyte surface, and then sintered at 1050 °C for 4 h in air. The microstructures of the composite electrodes/electrolyte were studied with SEM (Hitachi, S-570). 2.2 Electrical and electrochemical characterization The conductivity of BSCF4 and BSCF4–SDC sintered at 1100 °C (relative density about 90%) for 4 h was tested by the four-probe method, which carried out on a Keithley 2400 digital source meter and an AI 708 temperature meter controlled by computer through GPIB and RS-485 interfaces, respectively, from 50 to 850 °C. The electrochemical performances were investigated with three-electrode method. Prepared cathode on SDC was used as working electrode (WE) and reference electrode (RE), while counter electrode was arranged on the other side of the electrolyte disk using silver paste by pyrolysis. The polarization curves were measured using Electrochemical Interface (SI 1287) with potentiodynamic mode and the IR compensation was carried out with current interrupt method to take out the Ohm polarization. Impedance measurements were performed using an Impedance/Gain-phase Analyzer (SI 1260) with condition of 10 mV AC signal, 0.1 Hz to 910 kHz frequencies. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Phase construction The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the BSCF4 powder calcined at 950 °C and BSCF4–SDC30 calcined at 1000 °C are shown in Fig. 1 . It is known that the BSCF4 was of single phase with a cubic perovskite structure [14] . However, the BSCF4–SDC30 was not of single phase but a mixture with additional impurity phases. There were new peak appearing in the pattern of BSCF4–SDC30, and the main peaks for BSCF4 in the BSCF4–SDC30 shift obviously to the high angle direction indicating the shrinking of lattice parameter. At the same time, the SDCs peak at 28.36° also shift to 28.60°, which can be seen clearly in the magnified XRD pattern for the Bragg angle range of 27° ≤ 2 θ ≤ 35° ( Fig. 1 b). It means that some Sm 3+ ion left ceria lattice since the lattice constant of Sm doped ceria (SDC) is larger than that of undoped ceria [15] . We concluded that BSCF4 reacted with SDC during the sintering process; the conceivable condition maybe: some Sm 3+ ion left SDC, gone to the lattice of BSCF4 forming the layer sequence perovskite [16–18] . The exact crystal structure of the production will be studied seriously in the further work. 3.2 Electrical conductivity Fig. 2 shows the temperature dependence of electrical conductivity of sintered BSCF4, SDC and the BSCF4–SDC. As can be seen, at low temperature (∼400 °C), the Arrhenius relationship curves of the entire sample were almost liner, but there were obvious inflections appeared at 400–500 °C, and then the curves became flat. In addition, the conductivity of BSCF4–SDC was higher than the pure BSCF4 and SDC at all temperatures. As a mix conductor, the total conductivity of BSCF4 involves an electronic and an ionic conductivity term, due to the presence of holes and oxygen vacancies. The ionic conductivity is lower than electronic nearly one magnitude; it is reasonable to assume that the measured values mainly refer to the former one. The conductivity can be believed to occur by the hopping of P-type small polarons, associated with the behaviors of tetravalent state of cobalt and iron cations [14] . Under lower temperature (<400 °C), the charge transfer is thermally activated, with the temperature dependence given by the equation: (1) σ = A T exp − E a k T where E a is activation energy for hopping. The inflection on the Arrhenius plots at 400–500 °C were attributed to the oxygen loss during the temperature rising up and the thermal reduction of Co 4+ and Fe 4+ [14] . The conductivity of the BSCF4–SDC involves the contribution of BSCF4 and SDC. As an ionic conductor, the conductivity of SDC is lower than the mixed conductor BSCF4 (as shown in Table 1 ); hence BSCF4 plays the main role for the conductivity of BSCF4–SDC. For BSCF4–SDC, part Sm 3+ diffused from SDC into the BSCF4, as proved by XRD result influenced the conductivity. The introduction of Sm 3+ hoisted the average valence of A-site in BSCF4 thus induced the reduction of Co and Fe ions in B-site to maintain the electrical neutrality, and then enhanced the conductivity. To make sure the role of Sm 3+ , Sm 3+ was brought in the A-site of BSCF4 straightly to get (Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 ) 0.8 Sm 0.2 Fe 0.8 Co 0.2 O 3− δ (BSSCF). As expected, the conductivity of BSSCF is higher than that of BSCF4 ( Fig. 2 ), which confirm the transfer of Sm 3+ , increased the concentration of carrier, and the electrical conductivity was enhanced [15,16] . The specific conductivity values at various temperature points are listed in Table 1 . The maximum conductivity for BSCF4–SDC appeared at about 400 °C differing from that of BSCF4 at about 600 °C. Among all the samples, BSCF4–SDC20 showed the highest conductivity. The conductivity of BSCF4–SDC with mixed conductor (BSCF4) and ionic conductor (SDC) is influenced by such factors: the conductivity of each component, the ratio of them and the microstructure. With the increasing of SDC (ionic conductor) ratio, the ionic conductivity of composite material is increasing, while the electronic conductivity arose by BSCF4 is decreasing with the reduction of BSCF4 ratio. The synthetically effect is the BSCF4–SDC20 having the highest conductivity [19–21] 3.3 TEC measurements Fig. 3 gives out the thermal expansion results, and Table 2 list the specific TEC values. It can be seen, similar to other Co-based materials, the TECs of BSCF4 were extraordinary high, with the value of about 19.7 × 10 −6 K −1 in air from 30 to 800 °C. As shown in Fig. 3 , there were inflections for all these curves. Inflection of BSCF4 was found at about 510 °C, while the ones of the BSCF4–SDC were at about 300 °C. The occurrence of inflection points might attribute to the loss of lattice oxygen and the formation of oxygen vacancies corresponding to the phenomenon of electrical conductivity related. For the BSCF4–SDC, as seen in Table 2 , the addition of SDC lowered the TECs; e.g., the BSCF4–SDC40 lowered the thermal expansion coefficient about 18%. Thus the composite material BSCF4–SDC reduced the thermal expansion mismatch problem of BSCF4 as expected. 3.4 Microstructure characterization The microstructures of the composite electrodes on SDC electrolyte were studied by SEM. Fig. 4 a shows SEM micrographs of the fractured surface of composite BSCF4–SDC30 layer sintered at 1050 °C on a SDC electrolyte. The thickness of the electrode layer is 20–25 μm. According to the SEM micrographs, porous electrodes are apparent, while the SDC electrolyte is dense. It is also obvious that the composite electrode is not a uniform mixture of fine particles where the two oxides are separated completely from each other, but is, more likely, an agglomerate mixture of the two components. As expected the adhesion of the composite to the SDC electrolyte is excellent due to the addition of SDC minish the problem of thermal expansion mismatch. Fig. 4 b shows the microstructure of the BSCF4–SDC30 with mass pore, which ensure the transport of gas [22] . 3.5 Influences of SDC addition on the cathode properties Fig. 5 shows the electrochemical impedance spectra of BSCF4 and BSCF4–SDC electrodes on SDC electrolyte, which contains two parts. The left arc (high frequency) is contribution of Ohm polarization, including the effective resistance between reference electrode and working electrode, the DC resistance of leads and electrode, then the right arc (low frequency) is due to electrode polarization resistance, including the charge transfer resistance of electrochemical reaction at electrode–electrolyte interface, and the equivalent resistance for the oxygen adsorption, decomposition and mass transfer. The equivalent circuit is presented in Fig. 6 . The elements of the equivalent circuit correspond to the electrochemical process. R 1 corresponds to the resistance of Ohm polarizaton, R 2 corresponds to the resistance of charge-transfer process through the electrode–electrolyte interface, and W 1 − R corresponds to the impedance of diffusion, while the CPE 1 − T corresponds to the capacitance of the whole electrode. The fitting results of impedance spectra for various materials at 550 °C are shown in Table 3 . R el , the summation of R 2 and W 1 − R is considered to be the total polarization resistance of electrode. It is obvious the R el of BSCF4–SDC is lower than that of pure BSCF4. The decreasing of resistance is due to the following reasons. First, BSCF4 as one kind of mixed conductor contains ionic conductivity, thus the oxygen reduction occurs on not only the triple phase boundaries (TPBs) but also the surface of electrode. The adsorbed molecular oxygen is reduced to oxygen ions, and finally, diffuse towards the electrode–electrolyte interface and electrolyte bulk. The diffusion is influenced by the concentration of oxygen vacancies. The addition of an ionic conducting phase (SDC) increases the concentration of total oxygen vacancies and the oxygen diffusion is improved, so the resistance is reduced. Second, part Sm 3+ diffuse from SDC into the BSCF4 hoist the average valence of A-site thus induce the reduction of Co and Fe ions in B-site. The change of valence from IV to III weakens the astriction to oxygen ions, so the diffusion of oxygen in BSCF4–SDC becomes more easily. Third, the reduced thermal expansion mismatch problem improved the adhesion between the electrodes and electrolytes, thus optimized the electrochemistry performance of BSCF4–SDC. In this study, the composition of BSCF4–SDC30 gave the best performance; e.g., at 550 °C, the decrease in R el relative to pure BSCF4 was about seven times for BSCF4–SDC30. The present results had the best R el value of 0.298 Ω cm 2 (550 °C), obviously better than in Refs. [9,21] where the similar composite cathode LSCF-GDC had the R el value of ∼0.6 Ω cm 2 at 590 °C. Fig. 7 shows the current density j versus the overpotential η of various electrodes at 550 °C. As can be seen, the polarization current density under same overpotential varied with SDC ratio markedly, and the current density was enhanced by the addition of SDC, with the SDC ratio of 30 wt% showing the maximum current density, which was agree with the results of impedance spectra. The development of a series of new cathodes by mixing a mixed conducting phase (BSCF4) with an ionic conducting phase (SDC) results in a significant improvement on the electrochemical properties. And the contents of SDC have influence on the results. For example, the resistance of the BSCF4–SDC varied markedly from 550 to 750 °C, with the SDC ratio of 30 wt% showed the minimum at all temperature. Fig. 8 shows the relation between the electrode resistance and content of SDC. It is apparent that the resistances of BSCF4–SDC were not always reduced with the increasing of SDC, the electrochemical properties of BSCF4–SDC, such as the resistance, were especially sensitive not only to the amount of each phase, but also to the degree which phase were connected to. Similar conclusions have been obtained in SSC–SDC and LSCF–GDC composite system [21,23] . 4 Conclusion Incorporating an amount of Ce 0.8 Sm 0.2 O 1.9 (SDC) to Ba 0.5 Sr 0.5 Co 0.6 Fe 0.4 O 3 (BSCF4) to get a series of composite materials BSCF4–SDC. Then the composite materials were investigated in comparison with simple BSCF4 on electrical conductivity, thermal expansion coefficient, as well as electrochemical properties. The X-ray result indicated the reaction between BSCF4 and SDC during the sintering process that is the Sm 3+ cations diffused from SDC into BSCF4. The diffusion of Sm 3+ enhanced the conductivity of BSCF4 as expected. And the addition of SDC also lowered the TECs of BSCF4 sharply and reduced the problem of thermal expansion mismatch. The polarization curves and impedance spectra results showed that the composite materials BSCF4–SDC exhibited better electrochemical performance than the pure BSCF4. All things considered, the composite containing 30 wt% SDC (BSCF4–SDC30) with the lowest polarization resistance (1/7 of the pure BSCF4) is a promising material for IT-SOFC based on SDC electrolytes, whose stability and performance on single cell will be investigated in the future. qtvjlslT.title: Study on new copper-containing SOFC anode materials
qtvjlslT.abstract: A series of new Ni–Cu–YSZ cermet made of oxide raw materials was employed as the anode of a SOFC. The reducing properties of these materials were first investigated. The open circuit voltage was over 1.1 V, and the output power density was about 33–43 mW/cm 2 at 900°C. Altering the fuel gas between H 2 and city coal gas shows that the output voltage and power are affected by fuel, and the response of fuel cell to the fuel gas is rapid. When pitch exists in the fuel gas, a tar-liked carbon is deposited on the Al 2 O 3 tubes of the cell but not on the anode. It has been proved that the anode with Cu has a self-cleaning function.

dCYKNo4v.title: Effect of pressure and solvent on Raman spectra of all-trans-β- carotene
dCYKNo4v.abstract: The ground state Raman spectra of all-trans-β-carotene in n-hexane and CS2 solutions are measured by simultaneously changing the solvent environment and molecular structure under high hydrostatic pressure. The diverse pressure dependencies of several representative Raman bands are explained using a competitive mechanism involving bond length changes and vibronic coupling. It is therefore concluded that (a) the in-phase C=C stretching mode plays an essential role in the conversion of energy from S1 to S0 states in carotenoids, (b) internal conversion and intramolecular vibrational redistribution can be accelerated by high pressure, and (c) the environmental effect, but not the structural distortion or π-electron derealization, is responsible for the spectral properties of a given carotenoid species. These findings revealed the potential of high pressure in exploring the nature of the biological functions of carotenoids. © 2007 American Chemical Society.

H40p8dtM.title: Enhancement of low-field magnetoresistance in polycrystalline Sr 2FeMoO 6 with Al doping
H40p8dtM.abstract: The low-field magnetoresistance (LFMR) performance of Sr 2Fe 1-xAl xMoO 6 polycrystalline with x=0, 0.05, 0.10, 0.15, and 0.30, after fabrication, was investigated. It was observed that the LFMR was greatly enhanced as x increased from nil to 0.15, and its origin of the LFMR was found to be intragranular spin-dependent scattering. The replacement of Fe by Al weakened the antiferromagnetic exchange in the antiphase boundary and weakenend the ferromagnetic exchange. On application of the external magnetic field, the spin in the antiphase boundary aligned easily to the external field after Al doping and the weak double exchange barrier led to easier electron transport.

WHHhdCO1.title: Influence of nonmagnetic Al ions on magnetoresistance of double-perovskite Sr 2Fe 1-xAl xMoO 6 (0≤x≤0.30)
WHHhdCO1.abstract: The structural, magnetic, and magnetoresistance properties of the double-perovskite series Sr2 Fe1-x Alx MoO6 (0≤x≤0.30) were systematically investigated in order to clarify the influence of nonmagnetic Al ions on the magnetoresistance. The structural refinements of these samples show that the degree of cationic order increases gradually from 88.5% for x=0 to 92% for x=0.30 without any change in the crystal structure. The magnetization measurements reveal that the substitution of nonmagnetic Al ion for Fe ion enhances the magnetic moment per Fe ion significantly. In addition, the magnetic-field dependence of magnetization and magnetoresistance of these Sr2 Fe1-x Alx MoO6 samples were all fitted excellently by taking into account the contributions from ferromagnetic-coupled Fe-O-Mo region and nonferromagnetic- coupled regions. The fitting results indicate that the low-field magnetoresistance can be greatly enhanced due to the separation of the cationic-ordered Fe-O-Mo regions by the paramagnetic Mo-O-Al-O-Mo chains introduced through Al doping. Furthermore, doping nonmagnetic Al ions also suppress the formation of antiferromagnetic Fe-O-Fe antiphase boundaries, and then lead to the improvement of cation ordering and the reduction of magnetoresistance under high field. © 2005 American Institute of Physics.

uBMLUYJY.title: Preparation of YSZ film by EPD and its application in SOFCs
uBMLUYJY.abstract: An electrophoretic deposition (EPD) method was applied for the preparation of yttria-stabilized zirconia (YSZ) thin film on a NiO–YSZ porous anode substrate for solid oxide fuel cell (SOFC) applications. Dense YSZ film with uniform thickness can be readily prepared with the EPD method using isopropanol as solvent and iodine as dispersant. As EPD electrode, the NiO–YSZ substrate was covered with a graphite layer to obtain enough electric conductivity. A series of experiments, such as suspension concentration, sintering shrinkage, and so on, were conducted in order to optimize the EPD technique. A planar-type SOFC was fabricated using La 0.4 Sr 0.6 Co 0.2 Fe 0.8 O 3 (LSCF) as the cathode and YSZ film deposited onto the NiO–YSZ anode substrate as the electrolyte. The fuel cell exhibited an open circuit voltage of about 1.0 V and a maximum power density of 440 mW/cm 2 at 900 °C. Thus, the EPD method was a suitable technology for the formation of gas-tight YSZ film. Keywords Electrophoretic deposition (EPD) YSZ films SOFC 1 Introduction Recently the research of SOFC operating at intermediate temperature becomes more popular [1–5] . Two effective methods can be used to reduce the operating temperature of SOFC from conventional range of 800–1000 °C down to intermediate temperature (500–800 °C). One is to use alternative electrolyte materials with higher ionic conductivity at lower temperature [6] , and the other is to use the thin film technology of conventional electrolyte—yttrium-stabilized zirconia (YSZ). The latter is often adopted. There are many techniques applied to produce YSZ films. In these techniques, wet processes are especially attractive because of the low cost and mass productivity [7] . Electrophoretic deposition (EPD) is a noble wet process. The EPD technique was firstly proposed by Ishihara et al. for fabrication of SOFCs [8] . In EPD process, charged particles dispersed in a stable suspension are driven by a dc electric field to move towards an oppositely charged electrode, upon which they ultimately deposit and build up a closely packed particulate layer [9] . The advantages of EPD for SOFC are listed: (1) EPD makes it possible to fabricate the SOFC cells with any types of shapes; (2) Both dense and porous films can be prepared by regulating deposition rates and subsequent sintering processes; (3) It is easy to stack electrode and electrolyte layers; (4) Co-deposition is possible to prepare composite layers such as Ni-YSZ anodes, etc. In this paper, EPD technique was used to prepare YSZ (yttria-stabilized zirconia) film on porous anode substrate (NiO/YSZ). In this process, isopropanol was used as solvent and iodine as dispersant in YSZ suspension. The zeta potential of YSZ particles was studied by changing the amount of iodine. The effect of the amount of iodine and the concentration of YSZ suspension on the deposition weight was also studied. The prepared YSZ film and the anode substrate were then co-sintered at 1400 °C. The performance of a single SOFC, for which the YSZ film prepared by EPD process was applied, was tested. The short circuit current density and the maximum power density were 2.08 A/cm 2 and 440 mW/cm 2 at 900 °C, respectively. 2 Experimental The anode materials (NiO–YSZ) were prepared by mixing YSZ powder (China building material academy, Beijing, China), NiO powder (made by ourselves) and amylums (commercial) by a weight ratio of 5:5:1. The purpose of adding amylums was to form more pores in anode. The mixture was milled in agate mortar for 1 h. Then, the mixed powders were pressed into pellets with a diameter of about 13 mm and a thickness of about 0.6 mm. The pellets were subsequently baked at 900 °C for 2 h to form the porous NiO–YSZ as substrate. Generally, the EPD substrate should have some electronic conductivity at room temperature. However, the conductivity of NiO–YSZ is too low to be used as electrode of EPD, in this paper, a graphite film was prepared on NiO–YSZ pellets as conductive reagent, and it would be burnt out during the subsequent calcining process. YSZ suspension was obtained by dispersing YSZ powders (TZ-8Y, Tosoh Corporation, Tokyo, Japan) and iodine into isopropanol. In a typical deposition, 0.8 g YSZ and 0.04 g I 2 were added to a 100 ml beaker with 80 ml isopropanol. The mixture was sonicated with a high intensity ultrasonic probe for 10 min to form a stable suspension. The zeta potential of YSZ suspension was measured using a micro-electrophoretic instrument (JS94G + ). The experimental arrangement for EPD is schematically illustrated in Fig. 1 . NiO/YSZ substrate with a layer of graphite connected with the negative output of EPD power source was hung in the deposition cell as the cathode, while a graphite disk was placed on the opposite side of the cell acting as the anode. The two electrodes were kept parallel with a distance of 6 mm. With a constant deposition voltage of 10 V, positively charged YSZ particles were electrophoretically deposited onto the cathode and YSZ film was formed in 1 h. The green YSZ film was dried in open air for about 12 h and then co-sintered with the substrate at 1400 °C for 2 h. The sintering curves of pressed bars with powders of YSZ electrolyte and NiO–YSZ anode were measured utilizing a Netzsch DIL 402C/3/G dilatometer (Netzsch GmbH, Germany) with air purging (flow rate: 50 ml/min). In this measurement, the temperature was raised from room temperature to 500 °C at a rate of 5 K/min, and from 500 to 900 °C at 10 K/min, then being held at 900 °C for 2 h, finally raised the temperature to 1300 °C at 10 K/min and being held at 1300 °C for 2 h. The surface and cross-section of the sintered YSZ film was characterized using a SEM (Hitachi S-570 scanning electron microscope). La 0.4 Sr 0.6 Co 0.2 Fe 0.8 O 3 (LSCF) powder was synthesized by solid-state reaction method. Some adhesives were mixed with the powders to form slurry. The slurry was applied on the exposed surface of the YSZ film and then fired at 300 °C for 30 min to burn out the adhesives. Finally the sample was sintered at 900 °C for 5 h to obtain a positive-electrolyte-negative (PEN) component (NiO–YSZ/YSZ/LSCF). To make a single fuel cell, a PEN component was sealed onto one end of ceramic tubes ( Fig. 2 ) as the method mentioned in Ref. [10] . The silver layer on both electrode surfaces made from silver paste (DAD-87, Shanghai Research Institute of Synthetic Resin, Shanghai, China) was used as current collectors to collect current on both anode and cathode. Thus, a single fuel cell was prepared and to be tested. In the process of fuel cell testing, the hydrogen was used as fuel and the oxygen in air was used as oxidant. The anode chamber was purged with nitrogen below 500 °C, and the nitrogen was changed to the fuel gas (H 2 ) at 500 °C. The performances of the single fuel cell were measured using Solartron SI 1287 electrochemical interface (Solartron Instruments, Hampshire, England). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Electrophoretic deposition of YSZ The thickness of prepared YSZ film was lie on the deposited weight of YSZ in EPD process. In the initial period of EPD process, the weight ( w ) of charged particles deposited per unit area of electrode substrate is expressed as the following equation [8] , ignoring the charge carried by the free ions: (1) w = 2 3 C ε 0 ε r ζ η − 1 E L − 1 t where C represents the concentration of the suspension, ɛ 0 the permittivity of vacuum, ɛ r the relative permittivity of the solvent, ζ the zeta potential of the particles in suspension, η the viscosity of the solvent, E the applied potential, L the distance between electrodes, and t is the deposition period. Eq. (1) suggests that zeta potential of the particles is an important parameter in EPD process. The value of zeta potential is related with the solvent and the concentration of the dispersant [11] . In this study, isopropanol was used as solvent and the iodine was used as dispersant. The zeta potential of YSZ particles in isopropanol was plotted against the amount of dispersant (iodine) in Fig. 3 . Although the zeta potential of YSZ particles is only 2 mV in pure isopropanol, the value of ζ increases as the I 2 concentration increases and a maximum potential of 15 mV is attained at 0.5 g/l. The phenomenon suggests that protons (H + ) are formed by the reaction between I 2 and isopropanol: (2) I 2 + 2(CH 3 ) 2 CHOH → 2(CH 3 ) 2 CHOI + 2H + The protons are absorbed by the YSZ particles, and subsequently, the YSZ particles become positively charged. Corresponding to the change of zeta potential, the amount of YSZ deposited on the substrate changed. The amount of YSZ deposited at 10 V for 1 h versus the concentration of I 2 was shown in Fig. 4 . When the concentration of I 2 was 0.5 g/l, the weight of YSZ deposited on the substrate was the maximum. Therefore, the YSZ suspension with an I 2 concentration of 0.5 g/l was used in this study. From Eq. (1) we can also conclude that the deposition weight of YSZ particles is directly proportional to the concentration of YSZ suspension when the applied potential and the deposition time are constant. Fig. 5 shows the amount of YSZ deposited on the substrate at 10 V for 1 h as a function of the YSZ particle concentration in the suspension with I 2 concentration kept at 0.5 g/l. The weight of deposited YSZ increased linearly with the increase of the YSZ concentration when the YSZ concentration was below 20 g/l, but it reduced at higher YSZ concentration. It was also found that the YSZ concentration higher than 10 g/l resulted in poor quality non-uniform green YSZ films. This was probably due to the agglomeration of YSZ particles at high YSZ concentration and the high deposition rate, leading to poor packing density of the green film. However, if the YSZ concentration in the suspension was smaller than 5 g/l, the deposition rate was very slow. Therefore, the concentration of YSZ particles was kept at 10 g/l in this study to ensure both enough deposition rate and uniform green YSZ films with smooth surfaces. 3.2 Sintering shrinkage characteristic of YSZ electrolyte and NiO–YSZ anode Fig. 6 shows the sintering curves of YSZ electrolyte and NiO–YSZ anode. A typical sintering curve usually includes two segments. One segment is expanding, and the other is shrinking. At lower temperature, the sample expands with temperature increasing and shows positive thermal expansion coefficient (TEC), over a certain temperature, and TEC changes to negative and the shrinkage begin. According to the sintering curves, such parameters, e.g. TEC, starting shrinkage temperature, shrinkage rate and the total shrinkage ratio (sintering step) can be obtained easily. From Fig. 6 , it can be seen that the starting shrinkage temperature was almost the same but the total shrinkage ratio of YSZ electrolyte was larger than that of NiO–YSZ anode. This mismatch would produce stress during co-sintering process and some cracks in electrolyte film might be formed. So the co-sintering process should be controlled carefully. 3.3 Microstructure characterization of the YSZ films Fig. 7 shows the scanning electron micrographs of a tested fuel cell. According to the cross-section micrograph, the anode and cathode are porous and the electrolyte film is relative dense with few close pores. At the same time, the thickness of cathode and electrolyte are 12 ± 1 and 17 ± 1 μm, respectively. It can be seen that the YSZ film prepared by EPD technique was sintered well, namely, there is few pin-holes in the film region in both the surface and the cross-section micrographs. The grains were sintered together with clear boundaries. The porosity calculated by analyzing the SEM photo is below 1%. 3.4 Properties of fuel cell Fig. 8 shows the performance of the single fuel cell. The maximum open circuit voltage was 0.97 V at 800 °C. It was less than the theoretical one (about 1.23 V). This difference should be attributed to the open holes existed in the YSZ film. A small amount fuel may leak out through these holes and the potential of cathode may become a mixed potential that is lower than that of a pure air electrode. In addition, the shrinkage of YSZ film and NiO–YSZ anode substrate was different during sintering process, which would produce too large stress between the YSZ film and the anode substrate to form a few cracks which would influence the performances of the cell, not only the open circuit voltage, but also the current density and the power density. The short circuit current density and power density of this fuel cell were 2.08 A/cm 2 and 440 mW/cm 2 at 900 °C, 1.70 A/cm 2 and 390 mW/cm 2 at 850 °C, 1.28 A/cm 2 and 282 mW/cm 2 at 800 °C, respectively. 4 Conclusion Electrophoretic deposition (EPD) is an economical colloidal process. Furthermore, a simple apparatus is sufficient to realize EPD method. The present results show a dense yttria-stabilized zirconia (YSZ) thin film can be easily obtained using EPD in an isopropanol and iodine solution, followed by sintering at a temperature of 1400 °C. In particular, YSZ powder can be deposited on NiO–YSZ substrate with a graphite layer, therefore, the reaction between (La, Sr)MnO 3 cathode and YSZ was avoided at higher temperature in co-sintering process when LaSrMnO 3 was used as the substrate. The thickness of resulting film can be readily controlled by the applied potential and the deposition time. This study revealed that the EPD method is one of the promising methods for the preparation of YSZ electrolyte film for solid oxide fuel cells. UFvQoVe4.title: Structure characteristics and valence state study for La1−xKxTiO3 synthesized under high-pressure and high-temperature
UFvQoVe4.abstract: By using a high-pressure and high-temperature method, perovskite oxides of the type La 1− x K x TiO 3 ( x = 0.30, 0.35, 0.40, 0.45, 0.50) with mixed valence state were synthesized. This new synthesis route has several advantages. XRD analysis shows a cubic cell for the samples. XPS of the surface and EPR measurements indicate that the Ti ions have a mixed valence of 3+ and 4+ and that A-cation vacancies exist in the samples. As x increases, the amount of Ti 3+ ions and A-cation vacancies decreases. The valence state of the Ti ions can be altered by changing both pressure and temperature.

cUNRcNjA.title: A Method for Increasing the Three-phase Reaction Boundaries in Anode of SOFC
cUNRcNjA.abstract: A new method for increasing the three-phase boundaries in anode of SOFC is reported. The results of the study show that the three-phase boundaries in the SOFC anode Ni + YSZ are greatly increased by doping Ce0.9Ca0.1O2-δ particles, and the transportation of oxygen ion in the anode is improved as well. By adding Ce0.9Ca0.1O2-δ particles, the composite anode is produced and the anode reaction is accelerated, resulting in an improvement of SOFC output properties. The highest power density of SOFC with the anode of Ni+YSZ doped by Ce0.9Ca0.1O2-δ particles in a weight ratio of 15%, which is about 3 times higher than that of SOFC with the anode Ni+YSZ without doping, is obtained.

SGydTFdI.title: Enhanced photocatalytic activity of flowerlike Cu2O/Cu prepared using solvent-thermal route
SGydTFdI.abstract: Cu 2 O/Cu nanocomposites (NCs) with flowerlike nano-architecture were prepared using template-free stepwise solvent-thermal synthesis route with Cu(NO 3 ) 2 ·3H 2 O as a precursor. With the precursor concentration increasing gradually from 0.01 to 0.1 M, the morphology of the NCs evolves from nano-flower to microsphere. The content of Cu in the NCs can be easily controlled by adjusting the concentration of precursor and synthesis time. Using photocatalytic degradation of monoazo dye Procion Red MX-5B (PR) and phenol as the probe molecules under visible-light illumination, we have investigated the influence of Cu on the photocatalytic activity of Cu 2 O. When the content of Cu lies in the range of 27–71 wt%, the samples exhibit higher photocatalytic performance, indicating that these flowerlike Cu 2 O/Cu NCs are promising candidates for pollutant processing. Keywords Nanocomposite materials Chemical synthesis Electron microscopy Heterostructures

smqHEDDS.title: Synthesis and characteristics of nanocrystalline YSZ by homogeneous precipitation and its electrical properties
smqHEDDS.abstract: Nanocrystalline yttria-stabilized zirconia (YSZ) was synthesized by a homogeneous precipitation process using urea as the precipitation agent. The effects of powders calcinations temperature on the phase evolution, crystalline sizes and electrical properties were investigated. Characterizations revealed that crystallization started at about 773 K. Finely dispersed and weakly agglomerated nanocrystalline YSZ with the average crystalline size of 7 nm was obtained. During heating, a better crystallization and enhanced crystallite growth was observed. Sintering curves revealed that a densification process appeared in the temperature range of 773–1573 K with a well-defined maximum of shrinkage rate at around 1411 K. Raman scattering results at room temperature suggested that the major phase was cubic, and the minor one was tetragonal. On reducing the calcinations temperature of powders, the sintered ceramic density increased, corresponding to an increase in the pre-exponential factor and the conductivity. Keywords Nanostructured materials Ceramics Chemical synthesis Ionic conduction 1 Introduction Over the past years, nanomaterials have attracted more and more interest because of their extensive applications. Due to the reduction of grain size, the optical, electronic, magnetic and mechanical properties of nanomaterials have been changed drastically, and the sintering behavior of nanomaterials can also be influenced. For example, the sintering temperature of nanomaterials is about 200 K lower than that of microcrystalline materials [1,2] . With lowering the sintering temperature, energy is saved and new opportunities are provided for fabricating advanced devices. Due to the small grain size, nanomaterials offer new fields in application for microtechnology, surface coating for electronic devices and energy storage and conversion such as for the development of solid oxide fuel cells (SOFCs) [3,4] . Due to its nearly pure oxygen ionic conductivity and excellently mechanical properties, stabilized zirconia has been actively investigated and used in various applications such as oxygen sensors to monitor oxygen content in a gas mixture, oxygen pumps to generate controlled oxygen partial pressures and SOFCs to produce energy [5–7] . Many methods have been developed to synthesize nanocrystalline yttria-stabilized zirconia (YSZ) powders [8–11] . Homogeneous precipitation process [12–16] has been widely used to produce monodisperse metal oxide particles of various shapes and sizes. If the precipitation agent is added directly by simply pouring one solution into another, then there is little control of the chemistry reaction during precipitation because of the large and inhomogeneous gradients in solution concentration. However, a better control of chemical and morphological characteristics can be achieved if the precipitating ligands are generated simultaneously and uniformly throughout the solution, i.e. a homogeneous precipitation process. In this study, weakly agglomerated nanocrystalline YSZ was synthesized by homogeneous precipitation method. The objective of this work is to investigate the change of crystal structure, phase evolution, grain size and sintering behavior of YSZ nanomaterial induced by the different powders calcinations temperature. Especially, to provide a basis for comparison, the electrical properties of the sintered YSZ samples are assessed as a function of the measuring temperatures and the as-synthesized powders calcinations temperature. 2 Experimental 2.1 Nanocrystalline YSZ preparation Y 2 O 3 (99.9%) was firstly dissolved into a certain amount of nitric acid. ZrOCl 2 ·8H 2 O (99.0%) was dissolved into deionized water and mixed with the yttrium nitrate solution. This mixed solution was added to urea (99.0%) solution, and then diluted to the ZrO 2+ concentration of 0.05 mol/l and stirred uniformly. The stoichiometric solutions (molar ratio 4:23 of Y 3+ :Zr 4+ corresponding to 8% mol yttria-stabilized zirconia (YSZ) were transferred to a Teflon cup, and then put into a stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was heated to 358 K for 1 h to generate hydrogel precipitation. The hydrogel precipitation was collected by centrifugation and washed with deionized water repeatedly, and then dried overnight in an oven at 358 K in air, finally calcined at different temperatures for 2 h. 2.2 Characterization The crystalline structures were identified at room temperature by powder X-ray diffractometer (Bede Scientific D 1 , operated at 40 kV, 45 mA), employing Cu Kα radiation ( λ = 1.5418 Å). The average crystalline size was estimated according to the Scherrer equation [17] . Raman spectra were obtained with a HR800 integrated Raman system (Jobin-Yvon) at room temperature whose excitation source was a He-Ne ion laser of 632 nm. The grain size and morphology of the samples were investigated by transmission electron microscopy (TEM JEOL JEM-1200EX working at 100 kV). Sintering procedure was performed in air at a heating rate of 10 K/min. The calcined powders were die-pressed at 200 MPa uniaxially and then sintered at 1723 K for 4 h. The density was measured according to the Archimedes principle. A Hitachi S-570 scanning electron microscope (SEM) was used to examine the surface microstructure of sintered samples without any treatment. Ac impedances were measured between 0.1 Hz and 910 kHz with a frequency response analyzer using a computerized Solartron SI1260 Impedance Analyzer combination with a Solartron SI1287 electrochemical interface (EI). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 X-ray diffraction analysis Fig. 1 shows the phase evolution of the as-synthesized precursor and the powders calcined at different temperatures. The as-synthesized precursor and the powders calcined at 673 K are amorphous. Crystallization starts at about 773 K. During heating, a simultaneous growing and narrowing of the peaks is observed due to better crystallization and enhanced crystalline size. The evolution of the average crystallite sizes ( Fig. 2 ) was investigated during heating treatment. The crystallite sizes were calculated from the full width at half maximum (FWHM) of the first strong reflection (111) using the Scherrer formula. Results show that the average crystalline size is about 7 nm at 773 K. As the temperature increases, the crystallite size increases very slowly up to 1173 K. The rapid crystalline size growth starts mainly at above 1173 K, and increases to an average crystalline size of 51 nm at 1273 K. Crystalline size growth is the process by which the average crystalline size of the material increases continuously during heat treatment in order to minimize interfacial surface energy. When the heating treatment temperature is above the critical temperature, the crystalline size will increase rapidly. This can be the explanation of the sudden increase in the crystalline size at 1273 K. After the powders are calcined at 1732 K, the crystalline size is larger than 100 nm, which is beyond the scope of Scherrer formula used. Smaller crystallite sizes come from the powders synthesized in the presence of the high precipitation agent concentration. The crystalline sizes of YSZ are affected, in fact, by the nucleation rate, which is in turn proportional to the precipitation agent concentration. Thus, the higher the precipitation agent concentration reaches, the higher the nucleation rate will be, and then the smaller particle sizes result. 3.2 Raman scattering According to the X-ray diffraction ( Fig. 1 ), it is difficult to observe the tetragonal splitting of zirconia at low calcinations temperature (below 1273 K) due to the broad peaks characteristic to nanometer crystallite sizes, and there is still no splitting observed from the reflection peaks at high calcinations temperature (1723 K). Raman scattering [18] , on the other hand, is one of the powerful tools for observing the cubic-tetragonal change induced by oxygen displacements. Compared with the powders calcined at 1723 K, the Raman spectrum (obtained at room temperature) ( Fig. 3 ) of the powders calcined at 773 K shows broadly and poorly developed peaks, and the positions of all the peaks are blue-shift. The broad peaks have been interpreted by the breakdown of the wave vector selection rule by translational disorder through random substitution of doped cations and anion vacancies [19] . Small size and quantum size effects of nanostructure materials can make bands vibrating frequency heighten and energy bands broaden, which can cause blue-shift of Raman peaks. The Raman scattering results suggest that cubic phase is formed as major phase with a broad band near 630 cm −1 together with a background profile as reported in the previous works [20,21] . However, the bands of about 260, 330 and 475 cm −1 were included in six broad bands predicted by group theory for the typical tetragonal phase [22] , demonstrating that the samples prepared by homogeneous precipitation contain the tetragonal structure as minor phase. The Raman peak area ratio of the peaks at about 475 and 630 cm −1 , excluding the background, was used to estimate the relative content of tetragonal to cubic phases. The ratio of S 475 / S 627 (0.17) from the sample calcined at 1723 K is lower than that of S 476 / S 635 (0.23) from the sample calcined at 773 K, indicating that the sample calcined at high temperature composes of higher concentration of cubic phase. Yashima et al. [23] reported that the existence of t″-form tetragonal phase was difficult to distinguish from cubic phase by XRD pattern. Similar phenomena may have occurred in this study. A metastable phase (t″-form), which is a tetragonal phase with an axis ratio of unity, has been believed to exist near the tetragonal-cubic phase boundary. The cubic-to-tetragonal phase transition is not induced by the elongation of c -axis and shrinkage of the a -axis but by the displacement of the oxygen ions along the c -axis from the ideal fluorite site [19,24] . The X-ray diffraction is not sensitive to the structural change induced by the oxygen displacement in zirconia, although the difference between a - and c -axis lengths can be obtained by this technique. 3.3 TEM analysis TEM analysis provides information about the size and shape of primary particles and their state of agglomeration. Particles (calcined at 773 K) obtained by homogeneous precipitation exhibit well-crystallized nanocrystalline of homogeneous and weakly agglomerated assembly with the primary particle size of about 7 nm ( Fig. 4 ). This is in good agreement with the powder X-ray diffraction result. Results also suggest that the crystallites have nearly spherical morphology. Theoretically, the good sinterability will be achieved if the ceramic powders consist of particles with small size and soft agglomerates. Weakly agglomerated powders are needed for both dry processing methods of powders compaction, and the preparation of stable suspensions in liquids for thin or thick film production. The weakly agglomerated nanocrystalline YSZ powders, which are obtained by homogeneous precipitation, can be feasible to fabricate advanced ceramic devices. 3.4 Sintering behavior Dynamic sintering curves of the YSZ sample (using the powders calcined at 773 K) are presented in Fig. 5 . During sintering, the pronounced shrinkage of the green body is observed above 761 K, which is close to the crystallization temperature of 773 K. The shrinkage rate of powder compact increases and exhibits a higher value at 940 K. With the decrease of the crystalline size growth rate (between 973 and 1173 K) ( Fig. 2 ), the corresponding shrinkage rate decreases slightly ( Fig. 5 ). Above 1173 K, the crystalline size increases greatly ( Fig. 2 ), which further prompts the shrinkage of powder compacts. The shrinkage rate exhibits the maximum at around 1411 K. The total shrinkage is about 16.45% after sintered to 1573 K holding for 2 h. The crystallization process is the procedure of nuclei formation to crystalline and particles growth. During sintering, the growth rate of particles increases, which accompanies the agglomeration among particles. This higher physical agglomeration of crystallites originates from higher surface energy of smaller crystallite that causes the shrinkage of the sample. 3.5 SEM analysis The surface microstructures of sintered pellets (1723 K for 4 h) using differently heat-treated powders (773–1273 K) are shown in Fig. 6 a–e . Some small pores are observed when the sample sintered at 1723 K for 4 K using the powders calcined at 773 K whose average grain size is about 0.6 μm ( Fig. 6 a). As the powders calcinations temperature increase, the porosity of the correspondingly sintered samples (1723 K for 4 h) increased. Except from the sintered sample using the powders calcined at 1073 K ( Fig. 6 d) whose grain size is about 0.5 μm, the average grain sizes of other sintered samples increase with increasing the powders calcinations temperature, and increases to an average grain size of 2.1 μm using the powder calcined at 1273 K ( Fig. 6 e). The sintered sample using the powders calcined at 773 K represents the highest relative density (96.0%) ( Table 1 ). With increasing the powders calcinations temperature, the relative densities of the sintered samples decrease. The sintered samples using the powders calcined at 1073 and 1173 K achieve maxima of about 90.0%. The decreased relative density is ascribed to the higher porosity of the two samples. 3.6 Electrical property The electrical properties of the sintered YSZ pellets (1723 K), which used the as-synthesized powders calcined at different temperatures (773–1273 K), were investigated by impedance spectra at various measuring temperatures. The measuring temperature range of 923–1123 K was selected to simulate the operating temperatures of SOFCs used in general. Fig. 7 shows a typical Electrochemical Impedance Spectrum (EIS) response and its corresponding equivalent circuit for the sintered pellet (using the powders calcined at 773 K) measured at 1123 K in air conditions. The EIS responses of other measuring temperatures are similar to that at 850 °C. The high-frequency (47 kHz) intercept at the real axis gives the total electrolyte resistance, and the difference between the high-frequency and low-frequency intercepts at the real axis represents the silver electrode response. There is no grain boundary resistance arc resolved from the EIS response in the measuring temperature range of 923–1123 K in which the grain boundary resistance is negligible to the total electrolyte resistance. The measured conductivity data were analyzed according to the traditional Arrhenius equation [25] : (1) σ = σ 0 T exp − E a K T where T is the absolute temperature, K the Boltzmann constant, E a the activation energy for conduction, and the pre-exponential factor σ 0 is a material constant. Fig. 8 shows the Arrhenius plots for all calcined samples. Good linear relationships between ln( σT ) and 1/ T are observed. From the slope of the straight lines the activation energies can be deduced which represent the energy barrier for ionic movement during diffusion in the electrolyte. As indicated in Table 1 , all samples exhibit activation energies for conduction ( E a ) in the range of 0.95–1 eV, which are close to the values usually found for zirconia-based solid electrolytes [26] , indicating that the basic charge transport is identical in the studied samples. The temperature independent constant, σ 0 , which is a function of the charge carrier concentration, shows similar change tendency to activation energy for ionic conductivity, E a . However, there is an obvious increase to the pre-exponential factor with decreasing the powders calcinations temperature ( Table 1 ). When the Y 3+ content retain constant, with increasing the density of sintered pellets using the powders calcined from 1273 to 773 K ( Table 1 ), the charge carrier concentration values increase, corresponding to the increase of σ 0 . In fact, as seen from Eq. (1) , not only is the activation energy used to characterize the temperature-dependence of the measured conductivity for a given sample, the conductivity may also increase with the increase of σ 0 on condition that E a remains constant. Therefore, it seems to be more reasonable to analyze the combined effects on the conductivity by considering the parameters of both the activation energy, E a , and the pre-exponential factor, σ 0 . In the measuring temperature range of 923–1123 K, the conductivities of the three sintered samples using the powders calcined at 773, 873 and 973 K are pronounced higher than those of other sintered samples (using the powders calcined at 1073 and 1173 K). This result is due to the fact that the former possesses lower porosity ( Fig. 6 ) and higher relative density ( Table 1 ). The sintered YSZ pellets (1723 K) show increasingly relative densities with decreasing the calcinations temperature of powders used ( Table 1 ). The higher the relative density of YSZ pellet possesses, the higher the value of pre-exponential factor will be, leading to the higher charge carrier concentration, and then the enhanced conductivity results. When measured at 1173 K, the conductivity of the sintered sample using the powders calcined at 773 K is higher than those of the YSZ samples (measured at the same temperature) reported previously [27,28] . As shown in Fig. 7 , the conductivity for the sample of larger activation energy will increase more obviously with increasing the measuring temperatures than those of smaller activation energy. Slight enhancement of the activation energy is observed with decreasing the calcinations temperature of powders ( Table 1 ). The sintered sample using the powders calcined at 773 K shows the largest E a and σ 0 values to other samples. Therefore, it is reasonable to conclude that, at the measuring temperatures higher than 1173 K, the conductivity of the sample using the powders calcined at 773 K will be even higher than those of other samples measured at the same temperature. 4 Conclusion By homogeneous precipitation method, finely dispersed and weakly agglomerated nanocrystalline YSZ with the average crystalline size of 7 nm was synthesized when the powders were calcined at 773 K. With increasing the calcinations temperature of powders, a better crystallization and enhanced crystalline size was observed, whereas the corresponding conductivities of the samples (sintered at 1723 K) decreased. Compared with other sintered samples (using the powders calcined at 873–1273 K), the sintered sample using the powders calcined at 773 °C represented the highest conductivity. This resulted from its enhanced density leading to the higher pre-exponential factor which was closely related to the charge carrier concentration.
