RJc03VpN.title: Magnetic properties and colossal magnetoresistance of La5/6Na1/6Mn1−yFeyO3 with 0≤y≤0.10
RJc03VpN.abstract: The effect of Fe doping (0 ≤ y ≤ 0.10) in Mn site was studied for the colossal magnetoresistance material La 5/6 Na 1/6 MnO 3 . The same size of Fe 3+ and Mn 3+ causes no structure change in the series, yet conduction and ferromagnetism have been consistently suppressed by Fe doping. Doping with Fe causes no dominant lattice effects. It depopulates the hopping electrons and weakens the double exchange. ZFC and FC magnetization curve at 0.01 T field shows irreversibility. The temperature dependence of resistivity shows that all samples undergo a transition from paramagnetic to ferromagnetic with the decrease of temperature. However, for y = 0.10 sample, two obvious peaks are observed in the magnetoresistance versus temperature curve at 5 T field. The high-field MR effect may have its origin in a small canting of the manganese moments inside each domain even for H > H s . The canting angle becomes smaller and therefore electrons transfer more easily between pairs of Mn 3+ and Mn 4+ ions under high field. This will lead to a MR effect. Keywords Magnetoresistance Electrical transport Exchange and superexchange 1 Introduction Mixed valence manganese oxides R 1− x A x MnO 3 (R stands for rare earth metals and A for divalent metals like Ca, Sr, and Ba) with perovskite structure have been extensively studied due to the challenge of the theoretical understanding, as well as the application potential of the so-called colossal magnetoresistance (CMR) effect [1–3] . These perovskite manganites exhibit metal-insulator transition, various magnetic phases, charge ordering, orbital ordering, Jahn-Teller effect and other interesting phenomena. [4–10] . The double exchange interaction proposed by Zenner [5] provides a quanlitative explanation. The localized spins of Mn ions interact with each other via the motion of the conduction electrons. The spins of the conduction electrons are coupled to the localized spins and thus form energy levels according to the Hund's rule. Ferromagnetism facilitates the motion of the conduction electrons and lowers the kinetic energy. The electron transport responses to the variation of the magnetic structure induced by an external magnetic field, leading to CMR phenomenon. [8–11] . To understand the CMR mechanism, it is very important to perform investigation on the doping of transition elements at Mn site because of the core role of Mn ions in CMR materials. Mn site doping effects with transition elements have been extensively investigated [12,13] . The effects of substitution on the Mn site by other transition element is further known to affect the properties due to the changes produced in the average electron concentration and the shifts in the position of the e g and t g sub-bands. A number of studies [14] have been conducted on the effects of the substitution of Mn by various transition elements. The case of Fe is particularly interesting because of the large extent to which it can substitute for Mn. Ahn [15] et al. show that the observed decrease in T C in consistent with a weakening of the double exchange on the introduction of the Fe. It is apparent, from various studies,that the Fe atom substitutes for Mn at s valence state of +3 and is not involved in double exchange,thereby leading to a lowering of T C . Recent studies [16–18] have shown that the onset of the paramagnetic to ferromagnetic transition is accompanied by a divergence of the correlation length, signaling the growth of the infinite correlation and an inhomogeneous type of ferromagnetic transition. It can be expected that the effect of the Fe doping result in the formation of cluster and the suppression of conductivity. We have conducted a study of the magnetic and transport effect in a series of Fe-doped CMR compounds of La 5/6 Na 1/6 Mn 1− y Fe y O 3 with y varying as 0 ≤ y ≤ 0.1. 2 Experiments La 5/6 Na 1/6 Mn 1− y Fe y O 3 ( y = 0, 0.05, 0.10) bulk samples were synthesized by sol–gel technique. Stoichiometric nitrates dissolved in aqueous solution were used as the starting chemicals. Citric acid was used as the chelating reagent. After adding a suitable amount of citric acid to the solution and stirring, uniform gel was obtained which then evaporated at about 110 °C to yield a xerogel mixture. The gelatin was subsequently calcined at 400 °C for 5 h to decompose the organic substance. The resultant powder was then ground, pelletized and sintered at 1000 °C for 18 h with an intermediate regrinding, then furnace cooled to room temperature. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) was performed with a Cu Kα radiation. The temperature dependence of magnetization ( M – T ) under both zero field cooling (ZFC) and 0.01 T field cooling (FC) condition was measured by a quantum design physical properties measurement system (PPMS). The temperature dependence of resistivity ( ρ – T ) was measured by the standard four-probe method from 10 to 350 K. The magnetoresistance (MR) is defined as MR(%) = [ ρ (0)- ρ ( H )]/ ρH × 100%, where ρ (0) and ρ ( H ) is the resistivity at zero field and applied magnetic fields, respectively. Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of the La 5/6 Na 1/6 Mn 1− y Fe y O 3 ( y = 0, 0.05, 0.10) collected at room temperature. All peaks were indexed on the basis of orthorhombic unit cell. The lattice parameters are a = 0.549, b = 0.547 and c = 0.775 nm. We do not observe any appreciable change in the lattice parameters with increasing Fe concentration. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Magnetic properties The temperature dependence of the dc magnetization M ( T ) measured in zero-field-cooled (ZFC) and field-cooled (FC) modes under an applied of 0.01 T is shown in Fig. 2 for all samples. It shows typical ferromagnetic features. The Curie temperature T C (defined as the peak temperature of the d M /d T versus T curve) as well as low-temperature magnetization decreases with increasing Fe doping level. Irreversibility between the ZFC and FC magnetization curves is clearly seen close to the ferromagnetic transition temperature T C . The thermomagnetic irreversibility arises from the magnetic anisotropy due to the difference between FC and ZFC measurements. The response of the spin to the external magnetic field depends on the competition between magnetocrystalline anisotropy energy and the applied magnetic field strength. At low measuring fields, compared to the anisotropy field, all the spins will not be oriented in the direction of the applied magnetic field. The magnitude of M ZFC at low temperature below the T C will depend on the anisotropy. The difference between M FC and M ZFC will be larger for the highly anisotropic compounds. Hence, the irreversibility between M FC and M ZFC are due to their magnetic anisotropy. The magnetization as a function of the applied magnetic field at 10 K is showed in Fig. 3 . It can be seen that for all samples, the magnetizations reach saturation at about 1 T and remain almost constant up to 5 T. It is considered as a result of the rotation of the magnetic domain under the action of the applied magnetic field. The value of the saturated magnetic moment for all samples decreases with the addition of Fe as shown inset of Fig. 3 . 3.2 Electrical properties The temperature dependence of the resistivity for La 5/6 Na 1/6 Mn 1− y Fe y O 3 ( y = 0, 0.05, 0.10) at H = 0 T, H = 1 T and H = 5 T from 10 to 300 K is shown in Fig. 4 . The measured data shows fairly sharp metal-insulator transition at T IM . The resistivity enhances with the increasing doping content, while decreases with the applied field. The insulator–metal transition temperature ( T IM ) shifts to lower temperature with the increasing of Fe content. In the perovskite oxides [19,20] , the 3d level of the Mn and Fe ions is known to split into t 2g↑ , e g↑ , t 2g↓ , and e g↓ . The electronic configurations are t 2 g ↑ 3 e g ↑ 2 for Fe 3+ , t 2 g ↑ 3 e g ↑ 1 for Fe 4+ and Mn 3+ , and t 2 g ↑ 3 e g ↑ 0 for Mn 4+ , respectively. For these ions, the t 2g↑ bands are fully occupied.The t 2g↓ and e g↓ bands are empty. The e g↑ bands, which can accommodate a maximum of two electrons per ion, play a crucial role. In a mixed system of Fe and Mn, the widths and energies of their e g↑ bands indicate the electron distribution of the Fe and Mn ions. Ahn et al. [21] studied the effect of Fe-doping on transport property of La 1− x Ca x Mn 1− y Fe y O 3 ( x = 0.37 and 0.53, y < 0.2), and proposed that the Fermi surface of the system lie at 0.14–0.29 eV above the top of the Fe e g↑ band. Electron hopping from Mn to Fe is energetically forbidden even at room temperature. Consequently, double exchange is suppressed, resulting in the reduction of ferromagnetism and metallic conduction. Furthermore the T C and saturation magnetization are decreased while the ρ and CMR are increased. In order to discuss further physical mechanism of transport properties, we fit the curve of resistivity versus temperature when T > T IM using Mott's variable range hopping expression In ( ρ ) ∼ ( T 0 / T ) 1/4 , K B T 0 ≈ 18/[ ζ 3 N ( E )] [22–24] . In this expression ξ is the localization of length and N ( E ) is the density of states. The y = 0.10 sample is fitted as shown in Fig. 6 .The better accordance with variable range hopping modes indicates the formation of cluster or domain where e g↑ electron has to hop between them resulting in a semiconducting behaviors. The fit results can give T 0 that can be used to obtain the confinement length ξ . With the density of states N ( E ) = 9 × 10 26 m 3 ev −1 (Ref. 25) and T 0 , it is found that the localization length decreases from ξ ≈ 0.066 nm for y = 0, ξ ≈ 0.021 nm for y = 0.05 and ξ ≈ 0.005 nm for y = 0.10, which indicates the increase of the charge-carrier localization intensity. It also indicates that double exchange interaction decreases with the increase of the Fe-doping level, possibly due to the formation of magnetic cluster. In the low-temperature ( T < T IM ) where the transport property shows the metallic state, it seems to be governed by the electron scattering process. ρ ( T ) is well fit by the empirical equation ρ = ρ 0 + σ T n ( n = 2 and 2.5). Here ρ 0 associates with the domain boundaries and other temperature-independent scattering mechanism. [26] The result indicates that for the ρ ( T ) with y = 0.05 and 0.10, the equation with n = 2.5 fits the data well, which represents a combination effect of electron–electron, electron–phonon, and electron–magnon scattering. However, for the ρ ( T ) with y = 0, the equation with n = 2 fits the data better, which shows that the resistivity is mainly attributed to the electron–electron scattering. The results indicate that the addition of Fe significantly increases the electron–phonon interaction, which does not favor the moving of the charge carriers. So the resistivity enhances with the increasing Fe-doped level. The temperature dependence of the MR under applied field 5 T is presented in Fig. 5 . It can be seen that the MR of the sample with y = 0.10 is larger than y = 0 and y = 0.05 at the same fields and two pronounced peaks can also be observed. The higher temperature peak just occurs at about T C , indicating that it mainly originates from the intrinsic CMR, according to previous reports. [19,27] The physical origin of the MR effect in the high-temperature region has possibly been explained by the existence of magnetic polarons near the ferromagnetic transition temperature and their effect on the electron transport with and without an external field. Well below T C the manganese ions are ferromagnetical ordered. Inside a single magnetic domain the electron transfer between pairs of Mn 3+ and Mn 4+ ions is easy. But for an unmagnetized specimen there exist many domains that have different magnetization directions. Near the domain-wall boundaries, the pairs of spins of Mn 3+ and Mn 4+ may not be parallel. As a result the electron transfer between pairs of Mn 3+ and Mn 4+ ions across the domain wall is difficult and the resistivity is high. In a strong enough field, the magnetic domains tend to align along the field direction. As a result electrons are transferred more easily across the domain-wall boundaries and resistivity decreases. Our samples under 5 T field, the canting angle will become smaller and therefore electrons will transfer more easily between pairs of Mn 3+ and Mn 4+ ions. This will lead to a MR effect ( Fig. 6 ). It can be seen from Fig. 5 , the dependence of temperature becomes larger in high temperature region. The MR of the sample y = 0.1 drops rapidly with increasing temperature. In the high doping sample, magnetocrystalline anisotropy energy is lower than nondoped sample. So in the high temperature, thermal fluctuations induce to random potential. It is consistent with thermomagnetic curves. 4 Conclusions In summary, the polycrystalline La 5/6 Na 1/6 Mn 1− y Fe y O 3 ( y = 0, 0.05, 0.10) have been prepared by sol-gel technique. The structure, magnetic and transport properties are investigated. The results indicate that the structure of these compounds is orthorhombic, which proves the substitution with Fe has the advantage that it does not cause lattice distortion. However, the ferromagnetic ordering temperature and the saturation magnetization decrease with the addition of Fe. The thermomagnetic irreversibility arises from the magnetic anisotropy due to the difference in the way that FC and ZFC measurements are performed on polycrystalline samples. While the resistivity and the CMR increase with the increasing Fe content which strengthens the electron–phonon interaction not favoring the move of the charge carriers. The effect of Fe is consistent with the depopulation of hopping electrons and weakening DE interaction, possibly due to the formation of magnetic cluster. In the samples with high doping level, magnetocrystalline anisotropy energy is lower than underdoped sample. The high-field MR effect may have its origin in a small canting of the manganese moments inside each domain even for H > H s . References [1] L. Sheng D.Y. Xing D.N. Sheng C.S. Ting Phys. Rev. 7CKcZgiG.title: Preparation and characteristics of a glass sealant for IT-SOFC
7CKcZgiG.abstract: Intermediate temperature plate type solid oxide fuel cells (IT- pSOFC) are operated at 500-850°C, and the working gases between the two sides of electrolyte, fuel in anode chamber and air in cathode chamber, must be separated, so that a hermetic seal between cell components is essential. In this paper, a glass system based on SiO2-B2O 3-Al2O3-Na2O-PbO2-ZnO was prepared and the contents were optimized to determine the best material named T24. The softening point and viscosity at high temperature calculated based on thermal expansion curve are 840 K and 105 Pa.s (at 1198 K), respectively. The optimum sealing temperature range is between 1138 and 1173 K. The particle size distribution curves of powders ball-milled for different time were measured by laser light scatter method. After sealing, T24 glass sealant adhered with YSZ electrolyte well and there were no perforative pores in the sealant. The open circuit voltage of single cell sealed with this sealant was near theoretical value.

KrPqfDno.title: Evidence of two distinct dynamical freezing processes in single-layered perovskite La0.7Sr1.3CoO4
KrPqfDno.abstract: The static and dynamic features of magnetization have been investigated in terms of dc magnetization, ac susceptibility, and memory effects on single-layered perovskite La0.7Sr1.3CoO4. The results indicate that short-range ferromagnetic clusters coexist with the glassy magnetic state, i.e., a cluster-glass phase between Tf and T G and a spin-glass-like phase below Tf. The clear evidence of memory effects in the dc magnetization is also observed below Tf and TG, respectively. These two glassy states with cooperative relaxation processes may derive from the different interaction processes among nanoscale ferromagnetic clusters mediated by the matrix, which is influenced by changing the spin state of Co3 + ions in spontaneously phase-separated cobaltite. © 2011 IOP Publishing Ltd.

IAXrKWHF.title: Fabrication and characterization of multicore superparamagnetic Ni0.5Zn0.5Fe2 O4/SiO2 catalyst support
IAXrKWHF.abstract: A multicore superparamagnetic Ni0.5Zn0.5Fe2 O4/SiO2 catalyst support was synthesized by slightly modifying the conventional preparation method, namely, altering the manner of introducing Ni0.5Zn0.5Fe2 O4 nanoparticles into TEOS. The modified method resulted in a great increase in specific surface area, saturation magnetization of Ni0.5Zn0.5Fe2 O4/SiO2 and better separation in liquid system. The synthesized catalyst supports were characterized by means of X-ray diffraction, N2 gas adsorption-desorption experiments, transmission electron microscopy and a physical properties measurement system (PPMS).

SxKubKrz.title: Thermoelectric properties of highly textured NaCo2O4 ceramics
SxKubKrz.abstract: NaCo2O4 thermoelectric oxide ceramics with high crystallographic anisotropy were synthesized successfully by combining the traditional solid-state reaction and cold high pressure compacting method. XRD and SEM measurements show that the sintering after cold-high-pressure compacting is helpful to align the c-axis of layered grain within the sample along the pressing direction, i.e. the sample is highly textured. The thermoelectric properties of NaCo2O4, measured below room temperature exhibit a metallic behavior in both the resistivity p and Seebeck coefficient S. The sign of S is positive, indicating a p-type thermoelectric material. Compared with the samples prepared with other methods, although the thermal conductivity is higher due to the suppression of the phonon scattering by grain boundary or point defect, the above sample exhibits lower p and higher S which leads to the improvement of the ZT value that reaches 0.013 at 300 K.

xhrZKQAa.title: Second-order effects of the output resonance and frequency-locking in an electro-optic bistable system
xhrZKQAa.abstract: Based on the dynamic equations of an electro-optic bistable system with delay in its feedback loop, we theoretically investigate second-order effects of the output resonance and frequency-locking of the system.

3OBpr4MH.title: The Pr4+ ions in Mg doped PrGaO3 perovskites
3OBpr4MH.abstract: In this study, the valence state of Pr in Mg doped PrGaO 3 perovskites was investigated. It is found that Pr 4+ ions are created in samples doped with low-valence ions, for example, with Mg 2+ . The color of the doped samples changes from black to light green after being treated in H 2 atmosphere, which shows that the Pr 4+ ions in the sample are reduced to Pr 3+ ions. The open circuit voltage of the solid oxide fuel cell (SOFC) using PrGa 0.95 Mg 0.05 O 3 as the electrolyte increases with time and the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) data of PrGa 0.9 Mg 0.1 O 3 also show the existence of Pr 4+ ions in Mg doped PrGaO 3 .

nZlRH2YH.title: Fabrication and thermoelectric properties of highly textured NaCo2O4 ceramic
nZlRH2YH.abstract: Highly textured NaCo 2 O 4 polycrystalline sample was fabricated by means of the cold high-pressure compacting followed by the solid-state reaction. X-ray diffraction and scanning electron microscope were employed to show that the plate-like grains within the sample are aligned along the pressing direction. The resistivity ρ and thermoelectric power S along the preferred {0 0 1} plane were measured in the whole temperature range from 15 to 973 K in air and the correlation between thermoelectric properties and texture was investigated. It was found that both ρ and S exhibit metallic behavior in the whole temperature range and the above sample exhibits lower ρ and higher S due to high texture and density. The power factor exhibits a steep rise above 400 K and reaches 761 μW m −1 K −2 at 973 K, suggesting a promising candidate for thermoelectric application at higher temperature. The change of slope in both resistivity and thermoelectric power curves at about 450 K might arise from the spin-state transition of Co ions in the CoO 2 blocks. Keywords Oxides High texture Thermoelectric properties 1 Introduction Thermoelectric materials have recently attracted a renewed interest as a promising energy-conversion material in harmony with our environments. The performance of a thermoelectric material is usually characterized by the dimensionless figure of merit ZT = S 2 T / ρκ , where S , ρ , κ are the thermoelectric power, resistivity, and thermal conductivity at the temperature T , respectively. Although the materials with the highest thermoelectric performance are intermetallic compounds at present [1–3] , their application to power generation systems have been limited because they are easily decomposed or oxidized at high temperature in air. With respect to the high-temperature operation in air, metal oxides have obvious advantages for their excellent thermal and chemical stability. In 1997, Terasaki et al. discovered that NaCo 2 O 4 single crystal, which is characterized by a CoO 2 triangular-lattice layer consisting of edge-shared CoO 6 octahedra, displays high thermoelectric power of 100 μV K −1 and low resistivity of 200 μΩ cm at 300 K [4] , indicating a potential thermoelectric material. From then on, layered cobalt oxides, such as Ca 3 Co 4 O 9 [5–7] or Bi 2 Sr 2 Co 2 O y [8] , have been extensively investigated. However, the high cost and difficulty in mass-producing large single crystals limit their practical utilization in a device. An alternative way is to use polycrystalline materials and improve their thermoelectric performance by optimizing the preparation process. The transport properties of such cobalt oxides are highly anisotropy due to their layered structure [4–8] , suggesting that preferentially grain-aligned ceramics would exhibit higher thermoelectric performance than randomly oriented ceramics with the same composition. Recently, the correlation between thermoelectric properties and texture strength was demonstrated within the framework of Ca 3 Co 4 O 9 textured ceramics based on an innovative method of X-ray diffraction analysis [9] . With the above guiding principle in mind, many attempts, such as the reactive templated grain growth method [10] , chemical solution process [11] and magnetic alignment technique [7] , have been made to prepare highly textured ceramics. In this paper, we develop a method of fabricating highly grain-aligned dense NaCo 2 O 4 ceramics by compacting the powder under a cold high-pressure before sintering. The compacting under high pressure can decrease the distance among the reagent particles and enhance the reactivity effectively. By considering the layered structure of NaCo 2 O 4 , the grains are expected to align along the pressing direction after compacting under a high pressure followed by solid-state reaction treatment. Meanwhile, the grain size and bulk density of the polycrystalline materials can be improved greatly due to the sufficient contact among the grains treated by cold high-pressure compacting technique. 2 Experimental NaCo 2 O 4 polycrystalline sample was prepared by compacting the powder under a cold high-pressure before sintering. As the raw materials, reagent grade Na 2 CO 3 and Co 2 O 3 powders in the stoichiometric ratio were mixed thoroughly. The mixture was cold pressed into pellets under a moderate pressure of 500 MPa, and then calcined in air at 1133 K for 10 h. The pellets were pulverized manually for 1h, and then the powders were cold pressed into dish-shaped pellets under a high pressure of 2 GPa with a special WC die. Finally, the above pellets were sintered in air at 1173 K for 10 h. Also, we added 20% excess Na 2 CO 3 during each calcination and sintering process since Na tends to evaporate during the heating process. X-ray diffraction (XRD) data were collected using a Bede D 1 XRD diffractometer with Ni filtered Cu Kα ( λ = 0.15406 nm) radiation. The microstructure was observed with a HITACHI S-4700 scanning electron microscope (SEM). The temperature dependences of resistivity and thermoelectric power from 15 to 300 K were measured by using the PPMS (Quantum Design). The resistivity from room temperature to 973 K was measured by means of a standard four-probe method using the 2400 SourceMeter (KEITHLEY). The thermoelectric power from 373 to 973 K was calculated from the thermoelectric voltage collected with 2000 Multimeter (KEITHLEY) and the temperature difference between the two ends of the sample. Due to different measurement conditions the values for low temperature and high temperature regions cannot change smoothly. In order to eliminate this, we keep the values at low temperature unchanged and extrapolate and/or scale a factor for the high temperature values of thermoelectric power and resistivity, respectively. 3 Results and discussion Fig. 1 (a) shows the XRD pattern for the surface of the pellet processed by the cold high-pressure compacting before sintering, with comparison to (b) the crushed powder of the above specimen as well as (c) the pattern of γ-NaCo 2 O 4 in the JCPDS card (No. 27-0682). Powder XRD pattern (b) confirmed that the sample was crystallized in single-phase and no impurity peaks were observable. Compared with the patterns of the crushed powder and JCPDS card, the XRD profile for the surface of the pellet exhibited strong diffraction peaks from {0 0 l} planes. The (1 0 2) and (1 0 4) diffraction peaks, which are the second strongest in the JCPDS card, were hardly observed for the cold high-pressure processed specimen. It is well known that single crystal NaCo 2 O 4 consists of Na layer and CoO 2 blocks alternatively stacking along the c -axis to form a layered structure [4] , suggesting a highly crystallographic anisotropy. The XRD pattern (a) indicated that the c axis of the grains within the sample was preferred to align along the pressing direction after compacting under 2 GPa and sintering treatment. When the specimen was pulverized, the diffraction peaks from other planes exhibited, but the relative intensity of the peaks for the powder XRD was still different from that of the JCPDS card. It means that the large crystallographic anisotropy of the grains still exists in the sample after pulverizing. Generally, the degree of crystallographic anisotropy of these materials is evaluated in terms of the Lotgering factor [12] , f = ( p − p 0 ) / ( 1 − p 0 ) , where p = ∑ I ( 0   0   l ) / ∑ I ( h   k   l ) , and p 0 = p for a crystallographic isotropic (randomly oriented) sample. In this study, p 0 was calculated from the peak data of the JCPDS card, No. 27-0682 as in Ref. [11] . When the c -axis directions of grains are completely aligned along the pressing direction, the f value is calculated to be 1. The Lotgering factor f values of the pellet and its powder were calculated to be 0.94 and 0.71, respectively, according to the integrated intensity of the diffraction peaks in their XRD profiles. The value of 0.71 is very close to 0.70 for the sample prepared with traditional solid-state reaction method alone [11] . The f value above 0.9 has been found in the samples prepared by the reactive templated grain growth method [10] and critic acid complex method [11] , respectively. The f value of 0.94 for our sample indicates that a polycrystalline sample with a large crystallographic anisotropy can be fabricated by adopting a cold high-pressure compacting process before sintering. Compared with those above-mentioned methods, this method is simple and can be applied to more systems. Fig. 2 shows the SEM photographs of the oriented NaCo 2 O 4 specimen for (a) perpendicular and (b) parallel section to the pressed plane of the pellet. From these photographs, we can know that (1) the sintered sample was dense which is helpful for reducing the resistivity; (2) most of the grains in Fig. 2 (a) exhibited a large flat area along the pressed plane; (3) most grains exhibited a plate-like shape and were preferentially aligned along the pressing direction as shown from (b), i.e. highly textured polycrystalline sample was fabricated by means of the cold high-pressure compacting technique; (4) the layered structure of the grains can be clearly observed from the inset of Fig. 2 (b). All of these features are consistent with the conclusions reached from the XRD profiles. Fig. 3 shows the temperature dependence of the resistivity ρ for the oriented NaCo 2 O 4 specimen. With increasing temperature the ρ values monotonously increase from 2.25 μΩ m at 15 K to 38.7 μΩ m at 973 K, indicating a typical metallic behavior. As shown elsewhere, the transport properties of single crystal NaCo 2 O 4 exhibit high anisotropy due to its layered structure [4] ; i.e. the in-plane ρ ab and out-of-plane ρ c at 300 K are 2 and 70 μΩ m, respectively. The ρ value of 18.82 μΩ m at 300 K in our sample is about 10 times higher than ρ ab probably due to the charge carrier scattering by the grain boundaries in the polycrystalline sample. However, this value is much smaller than ρ c of the single crystal. Thus, it can be concluded that the electrical conductivity of the highly textured NaCo 2 O 4 specimen arises mainly from the transfer of charge carriers in the CoO 2 blocks. In the whole temperature range, the above oriented specimen exhibits lower ρ values compared with samples prepared with reactive templated grain growth method or solid-state reaction methods [10,13] . Such a reduction in the resistivity should attribute to the high texture and bulk density due to the high-pressure compacting, i.e. the alignment of the c -plane of each grain along the pressed plane as well as the decrease of grain boundaries reduce the charge carrier scattering. It was noticed that the resistivity exhibits a lower rise above 450 K as indicated by an arrow in Fig. 3 . Fig. 4 shows the temperature dependence of the thermoelectric power S for the NaCo 2 O 4 specimen. In the whole temperature range, S increases with increasing temperature, showing a metallic behavior as in the case of the resistivity. However, two changes of slope in the temperature dependence of S were observed. The rapid increase of S was first lowered at about 120 K, which was explained by the narrowing of the a 1 T band due to the c -axis thermal expansion [14] . From then on, the S increases almost linearly and reaches 172 μV K −1 at 973 K except a step rise at about 450 K. As mentioned above, the resistivity curve also exhibits a change of inclination at the same temperature. A change from a metallic behavior to an activated behavior in resistivity accompanied by a discontinuous change in the inverse magnetic susceptibility at 420 K has been observed in the misfit-layered Ca 3 Co 4 O 9 with the same CoO 2 blocks as NaCo 2 O 4 , and was attributed to the spin-state transition within the blocks [5] . It has been shown experimentally the spin state and the ratio of Co 3+ and Co 4+ ions in the CoO 2 blocks of NaCo 2 O 4 are the same with that of Ca 3 Co 4 O 9 [15,16] . Thus, it is possible that the spin-state transition occurs in NaCo 2 O 4 from the LS Co 3+ ions or Co 4+ ions to IS or HS at about 450 K, while the carrier density or the density of states near E F would be changed simultaneously. If these changes occur, the thermoelectric power and resistivity might exhibit a change at the temperature of spin-state transition due to the strong correlation among them. The slope change in the resistivity and thermoelectric power of NaCo 2 O 4 rather than a significant transition from metal to semiconductor in Ca 3 Co 4 O 9 might arise from the difference between the single disordered Na layer in the former and the rock-salt type Ca 2 CoO 3 layer in the latter. The sign of the thermoelectric power is positive over the entire temperature range, indicating the major conductivity carriers are holes. The value of 172 μV K −1 at 973 K is relatively high comparing with samples prepared with other processes, for example, Tajima et al. have reported a value of about 120 μV K −1 at 973 K for the oriented NaCo 2 O 4 specimen prepared by reactive templated grain growth method [10] . Although the preferentially grain-alignment with the Lotgering factor above 0.9 has been achieved by both the reactive templated grain growth treatment and the cold high-pressure compacting process, the grain size in the latter case can be larger than those of the former due to the large compacting pressure. This might be the cause of the relative high thermoelectric power. Power factor P of the oriented NaCo 2 O 4 specimen was calculated from the thermoelectric power S and resistivity ρ in the equation P = S 2 / ρ . Fig. 5 shows the temperature dependence of the power factor of the sample. After rapid increase from low temperature, P reaches a temperature-independent value of about 360 μW m −1 K −2 between 100 and 400 K. From then on, P increases steeply with increasing temperature again and reaches 761 μW m −1 K −2 at 973 K, which is relatively high due to the high thermoelectric power and low resistivity. Such a temperature dependence of P suggests that the layered cobalt oxides are promising candidate for thermoelectric application at high temperature. Furthermore, we can reach the conclusion that the thermoelectric properties of the layered cobalt oxides can be optimized through improving the texture strength and bulk density by means of the cold high-pressure compacting technique. 4 Conclusion Highly textured NaCo 2 O 4 polycrystalline sample was fabricated using the cold high-pressure compacting technique and its thermoelectric properties were evaluated in the temperature range from 15 to 973 K. The relationship between the grain-alignment and thermoelectric properties was manifested; i.e., the conductivity and thermoelectric power are effectively enhanced due to the high texture and bulk density. The power factor that reaches 761 μW m −1 K −2 at 973 K exhibits a rapid increase at high temperature, indicating the potential for high-temperature thermoelectric application. Thus, the thermoelectric properties of the layered cobalt oxides can be optimized through improving the texture strength and bulk density by means of the cold high-pressure compacting technique. E8XUjVAb.title: A Study of PrGa1-xMgxO3 as the Electrolytes of SOFCs
E8XUjVAb.abstract: PrGa1-xMgxO3(x=0, 0. 05, 0.10, 0. 15, 0. 20, 0. 25) were synthesized by using a standard solid state technology. XRD results show that all samples are orthorhombic. Mg-doping increases the oxygen ion conductivity and decreases the activation energy of the samples significantly. The conductivity of the samples is mainly ionic. PrGa0.9Mg0.1O3 has the highest conductivity of 0. 05 S/cm at 800°C, while PrGa0.8Mg0.2O3 has the lowest activation energy of 24.19 kJ/mol in all the samples. The oxygen ion transport number of the samples increases with increasing temperature. SOFCs results show that PrGa0.9Mg0.1O3 has the best properties, for which the power density of 0. 131 W/cm2 and the short circuit current density of 0. 45 A/cm2 were achieved at 940°C. This study reveals that Mg doped PrGaO3 is a kind of solid electrolyte with superior properties.

ZyizvVyf.title: Effects of Na2SO4 dosages on shrinkage and cracking of concrete at early age
ZyizvVyf.abstract: Effect of sodium sulfate, with a dosage of 1% and 2% (in mass) to blender respectively, on autogenous shrinkage and cracking of fresh concrete were investigated. Non contact concrete shrinkage measuring apparatus and plate type concrete cracking frame were adopted in this experiment. Microstructures of concrete, into which sodium sulfate was mixed, were studied intuitively by scanning electron microscope. Results show that the mechanism of sodium sulfate in pore with different pore sizes on autogenous shrinkage and cracking of fresh concrete are not uniform. Effect of sodium sulfate on shrinkage of concrete at early age correlates with the dosages of sodium sulfate as well as water/blender ratios. In the case of same sodium sulfate dosages, when the water/blender ratio is smaller the value of shrinkage at early age is bigger; while in the case of same water/blender ratio when the dosage of sodium sulfate is larger the shrinkage is smaller. Influence of sodium sulfate on the cracking of concrete correlate with different curing styles. Cracks at the surface of concretes cured in the air environments occurred earlier, wider and more than that cured in a sealed environment. Under this two curing styles the initial depth of crystals of sodium sulfate depends on the different rates of water evaporation, which is the main effect mechanism of sodium sulfate on cracking of concrete.

JjstgLex.title: High temperature transport and thermoelectric properties of Ag-substituted Ca3Co4O9+δ system
JjstgLex.abstract: Polycrystalline Ca 3− x Ag x Co 4 O 9+ δ (0 ≤ x ≤ 0.3) samples were prepared by solid-state reaction method and the thermoelectric properties were studied from 300 up to 1000 K. With the substitution of Ag + for Ca 2+ , the resistivity decreased while thermoelectric power increased simultaneously, and the thermal conductivity was found to decrease monotonically with increasing Ag content. These results indicated that the thermoelectric performance of the Ca 3 Co 4 O 9+ δ system could be optimized remarkably with the substitution of Ag. The power factor would reach 700 μW m −1 K −2 and the figure of merit ZT could exceed 0.3 at 1000 K for the x = 0.3 sample, suggesting a promising thermoelectric oxide candidate at high temperatures. Keywords Layered cobaltite Substitution Thermoelectric properties 1 Introduction Thermoelectric materials have attracted a renewed interest as a clean energy-conversion system in harmony with our environment. In recent years, the layered cobalt oxides have been investigated extensively since single-crystal NaCo 2 O 4 was found to exhibit a large thermoelectric power ( S ) simultaneously accompanied by low resistivity ( ρ ) and low thermal conductivity ( κ ) [1] . In this family, the misfit-layered Ca 3 Co 4 O 9+ δ , which also shows high thermoelectric performance, has attracted a considerable attention due to its thermal and chemical stabilities at high temperature in air [2–8] . Many experimental investigations have been carried out in order to understand and optimize the thermoelectric properties of Ca 3 Co 4 O 9+ δ [4,8–10] . Theoretical treatment of cobalt oxides indicated that the average valence of cobalt is an important factor determining their thermoelectric properties [9] , so the adjustment of the average valence of cobalt and thus the carrier concentration by doping is a feasible route to optimizing the thermoelectric performance [11–13] . For practical thermoelectric materials, a large thermoelectric figure of merit (ZT= S 2 T / ρκ ) is necessary, which requires a large S , a small ρ and κ . These three parameters are all the function of carrier concentration and interrelated to each other. Generally speaking, a decrease in ρ ordinarily results in decreasing S and a decrease in κ usually leads to an increase in ρ . However, it is quite interesting that univalent Na + substitution for Ca 2+ was found to reduce ρ and increase S simultaneously, resulting in the remarkable enhancement of power factor P ( =S 2 / ρ ) [11] . So appropriate doping would improve the thermoelectric performance of Ca 3 Co 4 O 9+ δ system and enhance the ZT value [8,12–14] . But as a light element, the substitution of Na leaded to the increase in κ , which is unfavorable for the increase of the ZT value. Therefore, doping Ca 2+ with a heavy ion, such as univalent Ag + , may reduce κ but maintain the decrease in ρ and the increase in S , so that the ZT value can be enhanced evidently. In this paper, we synthesized the polycrystalline Ca 3− x Ag x Co 4 O 9+ δ (0 ≤ x ≤ 0.3) samples and systematically investigated their thermoelectric properties at high temperature up to 1000 K. We found that the thermoelectric performance of the Ca 3 Co 4 O 9+ δ system can be improved remarkably with the substitution of Ag for Ca. 2 Experimental details The Ca 3− x Ag x Co 4 O 9+ δ polycrystalline samples ( x = 0, 0.05, 0.1, 0.15 and 0.3) were prepared by solid-state reaction method. Reagent grade CaCO 3 , Co 2 O 3 and AgNO 3 powders in the stoichiometric ratio were mixed thoroughly and calcined in air at 1173 K for 12 h. Then the mixture was reground, pressed into disc-shaped pellet under 450 MPa and sintered at 1223 K for 36 h under an O 2 flow with an intermediate grinding. X-ray diffraction (XRD) data at room temperature were collected using a Bede D 1 XRD diffractometer with Ni filtered Cu Kα ( λ = 0.15406 nm) radiation. The morphology of samples was observed with a HITACHI S-4700 scanning electron microscope (SEM). The resistivity from room temperature to 1073 K was measured by means of a standard four-probe method using the 2400 SourceMeter (KEITHLEY). TG measurement was carried out by using the SDT-2920 (TA). The thermoelectric power from 373 to 973 K was calculated from the thermoelectric voltage collected with 2000 Multimeter (KEITHLEY) and the temperature difference between the two ends of the sample. The thermal conductivity at 300 K was measured by using the PPMS (Quantum Design). 3 Results and discussion The XRD patterns for the pressed surface of Ca 3− x Ag x Co 4 O 9+ δ ( x = 0, 0.3) ceramics and the crushed powder of Ca 3− x Ag x Co 4 O 9+ δ ( x = 0.3) are shown in Fig. 1 , which are identical to the standard JCPDS card (21–139) of Ca 9 Co 12 O 28 , indicating the formation of single-phase compounds at room temperature. The XRD patterns for other compositions (not shown here) are the same as the above specimens, indicating that Ag was doped into the lattice of Ca 3 Co 4 O 9+ δ without obvious change in the crystal structure. The lattice parameters were determined by Rietveld refinement method based on the X-ray powder diffraction, using the profile analysis program FULLPROF. It can be found from Table 1 that the lattice parameters a and b 1 decrease simultaneously, but c increases strikingly with increasing doping content, resulting in a quite large crystallographic distortion. The ionic radii of Ag + and Ca 2+ in six-coordination are 1.15 and 1.00 Å, respectively [15] . Because Ag + is larger and heavier than Ca 2+ , both of the unit-cell volume and the values of bulk density of samples increase with the increase of doping level (shown in Table 1 ). It should be noted that the XRD profiles for the pressed surface of all the samples exhibit strong diffraction peaks from (0 0 l ) planes, but other diffraction peaks are quite weak, indicating the formation of textured structure in these polycrystalline samples. The SEM image of the specimen for parallel section to the pressed plane shows that most of the grains exhibit a plate-like shape and are preferentially aligned along the pressing direction, i.e. the high quality polycrystalline samples with a large crystallographic anisotropy were fabricated. When the specimen was pulverized, the diffraction peaks from other planes exhibited, but the relative intensity of the peaks was still weaker than that of the JCPDS card, which suggests that this strong textured structure in the grains was remained partly even after the specimen was pulverized, as shown in Fig. 1 . Fig. 2 shows the temperature dependence of resistivity ( ρ ) of Ca 3− x Ag x Co 4 O 9+ δ in the range from 300 to 1073 K. All the samples show similar transport behavior, metallic-like behavior below about 380 K and semiconducting-like behavior above about 380 K. The resistivity decreases significantly with increasing Ag content, and down to 7.5 mΩ cm at 1000 K for the x = 0.3 sample. The carrier of Ca 3 Co 4 O 9+ δ is hole [2] , so the decrease of ρ could be attributed to the substitution of univalent Ag + for divalent Ca 2+ , which enhances the hole concentration of the system. The plots of ln( σT ) versus 1/ T for all the samples lie on straight lines above 600 K, as shown in Fig. 3 , indicating hopping conduction at high temperature [13,16,17] . The activation energy ( E a ) obtained from the slopes of the plots [16] are almost the same for all the samples, as shown in the inset of Fig. 3 , which indicates that the Ag + substitution for Ca 2+ does not change both the E a of the hopping process and then the transport mechanism. Actually, in layered Ca 3 Co 4 O 9+ δ oxide, the CoO 2 layer is responsible for the electric conduction [2,6] . Ag was doped in the Ca 2 CoO 3 layer, and the conduction path would not be disturbed, and so the E a will keep constant. It can be found from Fig. 4 that for all the samples, there is an obvious M–I transition around 380 K, where the resistivity decreases dramatically. Ag substitution only reduces the transition temperature ( T M–I ) slightly, but does not change the intensity and shape of the ρ peak. In the CoO 2 sheets of Ca 3 Co 4 O 9+ δ , the threefold-degenerate t 2 orbitals will be split into a non-degenerated a 1 T orbital directed along the c axis and doubly degenerated e T orbitals directed toward neighboring cobalt atoms within the CoO 2 plane due to the rhombohedral distortion of the octahedron. The e T orbitals are broadened into a narrow band of itinerant-electron states by Co–Co interactions within the CoO 2 plane [18] . We suggested that the M–I transition here maybe a first order structure transition, caused by a discontinuous increase of the mean equilibrium Co–O bond length. With increasing temperature, the thermal expansion of the Co–Co separation will narrow the e T band to an e T orbital of localized electron state, and result in a M–I transition consequently. With Ag + substitution for Ca 2+ , because of the crystallographic distortion caused by the difference between Ag + and Ca 2+ ionic radii, the e T energy band will be narrowed and the Co–Co interactions will decrease, so the e T band will approach the narrow-band limit for itinerant electron behavior at lower temperature. Therefore, the decrease of T M–I with increasing doping level can be anticipated. It can be found that for the samples of x = 0–0.15, the ρ – T curves are quite flat above 800 K. The volatilization of oxygen from crystal lattice may be responsible for such transition, because TG experiments show the obvious loss of weight of these samples above 800 K ( Fig. 5 ). But for the x = 0.3 sample, the loss of weight is quite slight (less than 0.3% at 1150 K), and the ρ decreases more rapidly at high temperature. So we can see that increasing Ag doping level could restrain volatilization of oxygen, and the retainability of oxygen content would enhance the hopping mobility of carriers through a little change of Co 3+ /Co 4+ ratio [19] , which results in the decrease of ρ continuous with the increase of temperature. The temperature dependence of thermoelectric power ( S ) of Ca 3− x Ag x Co 4 O 9+ δ is shown in Fig. 6 . The positive S of all the samples indicates hole conduction in this compound, and the value of S increases with increasing temperature over the measured temperature range. It is quite interesting that S increases with increasing Ag content, similar to the results found in the Na substituted Ca 3 Co 4 O 9+ δ system and Ag substituted NaCo 2 O 4 system [11,20] . Such phenomena cannot be explained reasonably by classical theory, and should be caused by strongly correlated properties of electron. However, the carrier mobility μ ( ɛ ) may also play a crucial role in determining S in such layered cobalt oxides. According to Refs. [11,21,22] thermoelectric power can turn out to be expressed by formula: S ( T ) = c e n + π 2 k B 2 T 3 e ∂   ln   μ ( ε ) ∂ ε ε = ε F where n , μ ( ɛ ), c e , k B , ψ ( ɛ ) are carrier concentration, energy correlated carrier mobility, specific heat, Boltzmann constant and density of state, respectively. The formula consists of two terms and the value of first term c e / n is inverse of carrier concentration, but the increase of S with the increase of carrier concentration for Ag substituted samples suggests that the second term should be dominated in describing the S of these samples. We could presume that μ ( ɛ ) has been actually changed by doping Ag, which is the same as Na substituted Ca 3 Co 4 O 9+ δ system [11] , and just the change of μ ( ɛ ) results in the increase of S. Further studies should be carried out in order to clarify the nature of S in such layered cobalt oxides. The change of ρ and S with doping level indicates that thermoelectric performance of Ca 3 Co 4 O 9+ δ system can be improved effectively by Ag substitution. Fig. 7 shows the temperature dependence of P of Ca 3− x Ag x Co 4 O 9+ δ samples, which were calculated from the measured S and ρ in the equation P = S 2 / ρ . For all samples, the value of P enhanced with increasing temperature and Ag substitution results in the increase of P . Due to the considerable reduction of resistivity and high thermoelectric power, the value of P reaches 700 μW m −1 K −2 at 973 K for the x = 0.3 sample, which is nearly three times larger than the undoped sample and quite large for the Ca 3 Co 4 O 9+ δ ceramic. Fig. 8 displays that the value of κ for Ca 3 Co 4 O 9+ δ decreases monotonously with the increase of Ag content, which accords with the conclusion that substitution by heavy element leads to the reduction of κ . In addition, with increasing doping level, the scattering of lattice defect and impurity increase, which shorten the average free path of phonon and result the decrease of the thermal conductivity [23–25] . Generally speaking, for most crystal insulator the thermal conductivity will descend at high temperature. Actually, for nearly all the doped Ca 3 Co 4 O 9+ δ ceramic system the κ decreases with increasing temperature from room temperature to high temperature or keep nearly constant [8,11–13] . In this case, we could suppose that the κ of Ag-doped Ca 3 Co 4 O 9+ δ ceramic at 1000 K would not be higher than that at 300 K. Thus, we calculated the figure of merit ZT (= S 2 T / ρκ ) of Ca 3− x Ag x Co 4 O 9+ δ by using κ at 300 K. From Fig. 8 , the ZT for the x = 0.3 sample could exceed 0.3 at 1000 K and is much larger than that of the undoped sample. 4 Conclusion Substituting Ag for Ca in Ca 3 Co 4 O 9+ δ ceramics provides a significant decrease of ρ and increase of S simultaneously due to the enhancement of the carrier concentration and the change of μ ( ɛ ), which result in the increase of power factor P observably. At the same time, the Ag + doping could be advantageous for reducing the κ , so the figure of merit ZT value can be enhanced remarkably. These results suggest that Ag-substituted Ca 3 Co 4 O 9+ δ may be potential thermoelectric material for application at high temperature. 5AWe1TVU.title: High-pressure synthesis and properties of CeO<Subscript>2</Subscript>-ZrO<Subscript>2</Subscript> solid solution
5AWe1TVU.abstract:
Using nanoparticles of CeO2 and ZrO2 prepared by the chemical precipitation method as starting materials, the singlephase cubic Ce0.5Zr0.5O2 solid solution (cCe0.5Zr0.5O2) has been synthesized under 3.1 GPa at 1073 K for the first time. The structure of the c-Ce0.5Zr0.5O2 has not been changed before and after annealing at 773 K for 1 h. Only an unknown EPR signal (g =1.990) has been observed
 in the c-Ce0.5Zr0.5O2 and not varied after annealing at 773 K for 1 h, which exhibited that there exists no Ce3+ in the c-Ce0.5Zr0.5O2 and the Ce4+ has not been reduced into Ce3+ after annealing. The transport mechanism is ionic for the c-Ce0.5Zr0.5O2. The bulk conductivity (σ =1.2 ×10−5 S/cm at 823 K, σ=2.1 × 10−3 S/cm at 1123 K) is the same as that of CeO2, but smaller than that of Y2O3-stabilized ZrO2. A marked curvature at T = 823 K has been observed in the Arrhenius plot of the bulk conductivity. The activation energy
 below 823 K is lower than that above 823 K, and the reason has been discussed.

w9aQf2zM.title: Influence of doping Al at Fe site on the magnetic structure and magnetotransport properties of Sr2FeMoO6
w9aQf2zM.abstract: Double perovskite Sr2FeMoO6 with Al doping at Fe site up to 30% were prepared by traditional solid-state reaction. The degree of the cation ordering of Sr2FeMoO6 increases with Al doping obviously as shown by the refinement of room-temperature X-ray diffraction. The saturated magnetic moment per formula unit of these compounds decreases gradually with increasing Al concentration, but the magnetic moment per Fe ion increases markedly, which is consistent with the improvement of cation ordering. Basing on the analysis of magnetic structure with Al doping, doping of Al will lead to the formation of non-magnetic coupled Mo-O-Al-O-Mo chains, which can divide the large Mo-O-Fe ferrimagnetic region into smaller patches and enhance the low field magnetoresistance. The formation of Fe-O-Fe antiphase boundaries are suppressed by the doping Al due to the improvement of the cation ordering, and the high field magnetoresistance that roots in spin-dependent scattering at the antiphase boundaries is reduced. Therefore, the total magnetoresistance reaches a maximum value at x = 0.15.

R2avoX7d.title: The conductivity of PrGaO3-based perovskite oxides
R2avoX7d.abstract: PrGaO 3 -based perovskite oxides were synthesized using a standard solid state technique. In the formula Pr 1− x M x Ga 1− y Mg y O 3 (M=Ca, Sr), the solid solution limit is x =0.1 for Ca/Sr doped at A sites and y =0.2 for Mg doped at B sites. The oxygen ion conductivity increases and the activation energy decreases with increasing dopant concentration at A sites or B sites by single doping. However, the conductivity decreases when both A and B sites are doped, compared with single doping only. Mg-doped samples have superior properties, i.e. PrGa 0.9 Mg 0.1 O 3 has a maximum conductivity of 0.05 S/cm at 800°C, while PrGa 0.8 Mg 0.2 O 3 has a minimum activation energy of 24.19 kJ/mol in all the samples. With increasing temperature, the oxygen ion transport number of the samples increases. The conductivity of these samples is mainly ionic although hole conduction was observed. A power density of 0.131 W/cm 2 and a short circuit current density of 0.45 A/cm 2 were obtained at 940°C in the fuel cell experiment by using PrGa 0.9 Mg 0.1 O 3 as an electrolyte.

6qZmQxSX.title: Enhanced low field magnetoresistance in Sr 2FeMoO 6-glass composites
6qZmQxSX.abstract: In this paper, we report the enhancement of the low field magnetoresistance in Sr2 FeMoO6 -glass composites with different wt % percents of glass. The crystal structure of Sr2 FeMoO6 does not change by adding glass, and the glass is most likely located at the grain boundaries. The low field magnetoresistance up to 1 T of Sr2 FeMoO6 -glass composites at 10 K all shows obvious butterfly-shaped field dependence other than the pure Sr2 FeMoO6 bulk sample. The magnetoresistance of Sr2 FeMoO6 -glass composites at 10 K is enhanced gradually with increasing the glass concentration and reaches 39% with a wt % of 50%. The enhancement of low field magnetoresistance in Sr2 FeMoO6 -glass composites can be well explained by the spin-dependent tunneling at the glass boundaries, and it also allowed us to conclude that the spin polarization of Sr2 FeMoO6 is at least 80% at low temperature. © 2006 American Institute of Physics.

3xZUvj05.title: A new way of transformation from α-quartz to coesite
3xZUvj05.abstract: A laboratory method combining the high-energy mechanical ball milling and high static pressure has been suggested for modelling synthesis of coesite in the Earth' s crust. A window of milling time, a mechanical collision-induced intermediate phase of α-quartz and its condition of easily crystallizing into coesite under the condition of 3.0 GPa, 923 K, < 1.0 min have been discovered. The new method needs much shorter synthesizing time and lower synthesizing critical pressure than those used before. The Raman spectra for the coesite synthesized by the present method have covered all the information of those natural and synthesized coesites reported before. It is demonstrated that this method has a great potential in geo-science research and implied the other possible mechanism of coesite formation in the Earth's crust.

YPlgdIZh.title: Large intragranular low field magnetoresistance in polycrystalline S2Fe1-xAlxMoO6 compounds
YPlgdIZh.abstract: Polycrystalline powders of the family of compounds Sr2Fe1-xAlxMoO6 (x = 0, 0.05, 0.10, 0.15, 0.30) were prepared according to the standard solid-state reaction . XRD patterns and SEM images show that the structure and the grain size of these compounds were not changed and no impurity was observed by doping with Al in Sr2 FeMoO6. In the cationic ordered segregation, a large ferrimagnetic patch can be separated into some smaller ones by the Al doping. So the chain of the ferrimagnetic exchange path will be shortened and the strength of exchange will be weakened. Therefore, their moments become more sensitive to external field. Furthermore, when the Al ion replaces the Fe ion in the disordered segregation, the antiferromagnetic coupling becomes weaker. As a result, the low-field magnetoresistance is enhanced. But the smaller ferrimagnetic segregates become more sensitive to thermal agitation at high temperatures. The weakness of the Al-doped SFMO lies in its stronger temperature dependence of the saturated moments and the low-field magnetoresistance.

8ESHnbiF.title: Fabrication and thermoelectric properties of highly textured NaCo 2O4 ceramic
8ESHnbiF.abstract: Highly textured NaCo2O4 polycrystalline sample was fabricated by means of the cold high-pressure compacting followed by the solid-state reaction. X-ray diffraction and scanning electron microscope were employed to show that the plate-like grains within the sample are aligned along the pressing direction. The resistivity ρ and thermoelectric power S along the preferred {0 0 1} plane were measured in the whole temperature range from 15 to 973 K in air and the correlation between thermoelectric properties and texture was investigated. It was found that both ρ and S exhibit metallic behavior in the whole temperature range and the above sample exhibits lower ρ and higher S due to high texture and density. The power factor exhibits a steep rise above 400 K and reaches 761 μW m-1 K-2 at 973 K, suggesting a promising candidate for thermoelectric application at higher temperature. The change of slope in both resistivity and thermoelectric power curves at about 450 K might arise from the spin-state transition of Co ions in the CoO2 blocks. © 2005 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

uW0UIcBG.title: Strain‐engineered atomic‐layer movements and valence‐band maximum shifts in a two‐dimensional single quintuple film of Bi2Te3
uW0UIcBG.abstract: Recently, a fabricated two-dimensional (2D) Bi2Te3 single quintuple layer (BiTe-1QL) has demonstrated great potential in the application of electronics. However, detailed research of the deformation effect on this material is still lacking. In this paper, the deformation effects on the crystal lattice and electronic band structure of BiTe-1QL were studied by first-principle methods. It was found that tensile and compressive deformations in the x- or y-direction on BiTe-1QL caused both the movements of Bi and Te1 atomic layers along the x-direction, which can be explained by minimizing the deformation-introduced symmetry breaking. The position of the valence-band maximum of BiTe-1QL experienced a shift among critical points near the band edge with the applied strain. Moreover, −8% deformation in the x-direction causes the BiTe-1QL be a direct-bandgap semiconductor. The theoretical investigations clarify the structural and electronic properties of quasi-2D BiTe-1QL, and pave the way for its potential application in electronics.

50037Kql.title: Experimental and theoretical evidence for the ferromagnetic edge in WSe 2 nanosheets.
50037Kql.abstract: Bulk TMDCs are diamagnetic materials; however, two-dimensional TMDCs exhibit spin polarized edge states, which results in a coupling between the unsaturated transition metal and chalcogenide atoms at the edges. The magnetism in two-dimensional TMDCs broadens their applications in spintronic and multi-functional devices. Herein, by combining macro/micro-magnetic experimental measurements and density functional theory (DFT) calculations, we demonstrate that among five possible edge-terminated WSe nanosheets only two types have a magnetic ground state, corresponding to the 100% Se edge terminated and 50% Se edge terminated nanosheets, respectively. The calculation results on WSe clusters and WSe zig-zag nanoribbons with different terminations and Se coverage rate confirmed that the unpaired electrons of the edge atoms play a crucial role in the appearance of ferromagnetism in WSe nanosheets. Furthermore, due to the possible quantum confinement effect and surface effect, there exist thickness-dependent magnetic properties, and the magnitude of magnetism at the edge increases as the number of layers decreases.

GRgZLTCv.title: Colossal dielectric permittivity in (Al + Nb) co-doped rutile SnO2 ceramics with low loss at room temperature
GRgZLTCv.abstract: The exploration of colossal dielectric permittivity (CP) materials with low dielectric loss in a wide range of frequencies/temperatures continues to attract considerable interest. In this paper, we report CP in (Al + Nb) co-doped rutile SnO2 ceramics with a low dielectric loss at room temperature. Al0.02Nb0.05Sn0.93O2 and Al0.03Nb0.05Sn0.92O2 ceramics exhibit high relative dielectric permittivities (above 103) and low dielectric losses (0.015 u003c tan δ u003c 0.1) in a wide range of frequencies and at temperatures from 140 to 400 K. Al doping can effectively modulate the dielectric behavior by increasing the grain and grain boundary resistances. The large differences in the resistance and conductive activation energy of the grains and grain boundaries suggest that the CP in co-doped SnO2 ceramics can be attributed to the internal barrier layer capacitor effect.

SpyDoUcC.title: Voltage-controlled magnetoresistance of magnetite film in Fe 3 O 4 /Si structure at room temperature
SpyDoUcC.abstract: Abstract   In this paper, we investigate the voltage-controlled magnetoresistance (MR) of Fe 3 O 4 /Si structure prepared with pulsed laser deposition. The temperature dependence of resistance and non-linear I–V curve at room temperature suggest that the measured resistance is strongly influenced by the applied voltage and/or the current. The MR was observed to be dependent upon both the applied voltage and the angle between the magnetic field and the current. A greatly magnified low field negative MR ∼ −4% was achieved at 300 K and 500 Oe up to 3.0 V in the Fe 3 O 4 /Si structure, which originated from the release of charge accumulation at the Fe 3 O 4 /Si interface under the applied magnetic field due to the negative MR of Fe 3 O 4 .

7rdhXqjg.title: A Se vacancy induced localized Raman mode in two-dimensional MoSe2 grown by CVD
7rdhXqjg.abstract: Defects play a significant role in optical properties of semiconducting two-dimensional transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDCs). In ultra-thin MoSe2, a remarkable feature at ~250 cm-1 in Raman spectra is ascribed to be a defect-related mode. Recent attempts failed to explain the origin of this peak, leaving it being a mystery. Here in this work, we demonstrate that this peak is a Se vacancy induced defect mode. Heat effect and hydrogen etching are two main factors to introduce Se vacancies in CVD process of growing MoSe2. A phonon confinement model can well explain the behaviors of intrinsic Raman modes. Density functional theory (DFT) calculation reveals that single Se vacancy (VSe) is responsible for the appearance of Raman peak at ~250 cm-1 and this mode is an A1g-like localized mode which is also confirmed by polarized Raman scattering experiment. The relative strength of this mode can be a characterization of the quality of 2D MoSe2. This work may offer a simple method to tailor chalcogenide vacancies in 2D TMDCs and provide a way to study their vibrational properties.

8dCKt6Ni.title: Strong room-temperature emission from defect states in CVD-grown WSe 2 nanosheets
8dCKt6Ni.abstract: Monolayer transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDCs), as direct bandgap semiconductors, show promise for applications in ultra-thin flexible optoelectronic devices. However, the optical properties and device performance are greatly affected by defects, such as vacancies, present in these materials. Vacancies exist unavoidably in mechanically exfoliated or grown by chemical vapor deposition (CVD) monolayer TMDCs; therefore, their influence on the electric and optical properties of host materials has been widely studied. Here, we report a new defect state located at 1.54 eV, which is 70 meV lower than the neutral exciton energy in as-prepared MoS2 monolayers grown by CVD. This defect state is clearly observed in photoluminescence (PL) and Raman spectra at ambient conditions. PL mapping, Raman mapping, and atomic force microscopy analysis indicate a solid-vapor reaction growth mechanism of the defect state formation. During a certain growth stage, nuclei with the composition of WOxSey do not fully react with the Se vapor, leading to the defect formation. This type of defects permits radiative recombination of bound neutral excitons, which can make the PL intensity as strong as the intrinsic excitation. Our findings reveal a new way to tailor the optical properties of two-dimensional TMDCs without any additional processes performed after growth.

IRbsR6R9.title: The contribution of doped-Al to the colossal permittivity properties of AlxNb0.03Ti0.97−xO2 rutile ceramics
IRbsR6R9.abstract: The search for colossal permittivity (CP) materials continues to attract considerable interest motivated by not only academic research but also potential applications. Very recently, CP with low dielectric loss was reported in In + Nb co-doped rutile TiO2 polycrystalline ceramics. However, the mechanism of CP in this material system and the effect of doping ions are still unclear. Here, we investigated the dielectric properties of AlxNb0.03Ti0.97−xO2 (x = 0, 0.01, 0.03 and 0.05) ceramics. CP with low dielectric loss was found in AlxNb0.03Ti0.97−xO2 samples (x ≤ 0.03). Once the amount of Al-doping exceeds Nb, the CP disappears. The change in dielectric response with varying Al-doping concentration and Ti3+ concentration together with the conductive activation energy in AlxNb0.03Ti0.97−xO2 ceramics clearly suggest that the CP mechanism in co-doped TiO2 ceramics could be attributed to the internal barrier layer capacitor effect. We believe that our research provides comprehensive guidance for the development of CP materials.

EkXGud0R.title: Modulation of Void Motion Behavior in a Magnetized Dusty Plasma
EkXGud0R.abstract: Based on fluid equations, we show a time-dependent self-consistent nonlinear model for void formation in magnetized dusty plasmas. The cylindrical configuration is applied to better illustrate the effects of the static magnetic field, considering the azimuthal motion of the dusts. The nonlinear evolution of the dust void and the rotation of the dust particles are then investigated numerically. The results show that, similar to the unmagnetized one-dimensional model, the radial ion drag plays a crucial role in the evolution of the void. Moreover, the dust rotation is driven by the azimuthal ion drag force exerting on the dust. As the azimuthal component of ion velocity increases linearly with the strength of the magnetic field, the azimuthal component of dust velocity increases synchronously. Moreover, the angular velocity gradients of the dust rotation show a sheared dust flow around the void.

bOTyWQS9.title: Effect of Ga-doping and oxygen vacancies on the ferromagnetism of TiO2 thin films
bOTyWQS9.abstract: Abstract   In this paper, we combine first principles calculations and experiments to investigate the influence of Ga-doping and oxygen vacancies on the magnetic properties of rutile TiO 2  films. Ga-doped TiO 2  with few oxygen vacancies exhibits ferromagnetism at room temperature with a  T  C  near 350 K, which can be explained using a modified magnetic polaron model. The number of Ti 3+  ions increases with increasing the oxygen vacancies concentration, which results in a larger magnetic moment along with a higher  T  C  in TiO 2−δ  film with the ferromagnetic and antiferromagnetic coupling. The saturation magnetic moment is enhanced in Ga-doped TiO 2−δ  due to the absence of antiferromagnetic coupling after Ga-doping. More electrons occupy nearby Ti sites giving rise to the Ti 3+  moments. Our theoretical calculations suggest that the modified magnetic polaron model works well for the ferromagnetism of doped and undoped-TiO 2−δ . Experimental results clearly show that the  T  C  is related to the oxygen vacancies concentration, which is a verification of the polaron percolation theory.

tdCEeyCm.title: Analysis of Heavy Metal Pollution in Surface Sediment in Intertidal Zone of Qinhuangdao Coastal Area of Bohai Bay
tdCEeyCm.abstract: Based on the investigation on the surface sediment in the intertidal zone of Qinhuangdao coastal area,the pollution characteristics of Cu,Pb,Zn and Cd in the surface sediment were analyzed with their distributions evaluated with the Hakanson's potential ecological risk index.The results showed that the average mass fractions of Cu,Pb and Zn come up to the grade-Ⅰ of the national environmental quality standard for soil,while the average mass fraction of Cd exceeds 4.6 times as high as the grade-Ⅱ of the standard.The potential ecological risks of the four kinds of heavy metals are different in comparison,i.e.,Cd> Pb,Cu>Zn.On the whole,the ecological risks of Cu,Pb and Zn in surface sediment are all slight,whereas that of Cd is strong even very strong,which may hazard the littoral water quality and halobios.

kcauapTc.title: Analysis of evolution and prediction of water resource environment in Hebei Province
kcauapTc.abstract: This paper aims to present the authors' analysis of the water resource evolutional trend and study of the mechanism of the water resource system in hoping to be able to predict the future scenario by grey system theory.The results of our analysis show that,for the time being,the surface precipitation has been decreased under the global climate change.Currently,water resource system in Hebei has been disturbed by the over activity of human beings.Statistically speaking,annual exploitation quantity of the groundwater,in Hebei province only,has increased from 128.08 billion m3 in 1991 to 176.12 billion m3 in 2000,thus making the water resource development and utilization situation ever more serious.In addition,the quality of groundwater and surface water has been deteriorated since 1980,with the degree of mineralization and hardness of groundwater remarkably rising,which has brought about the phenomenon of dycarbonate-type and sulfate-type groundwater.Shallow beneath-surface water has become ever-going deepened from 1986 to 2000.The prediction of gray system shows that,the precipitation of the ground level of Hebei would have decreased in the near future to some extent.In spite of this,the exploitation quantity of groundwater would be increasing continuously,adding great pressure to the current fragile groundwater supplying system.On the other hand,water supply for agricultural irrigation would have to cut down due to the great pressure of human consumption just for living-making.Facing such a severe challenge,it would be inevitable for groundwater to increase its mineralization and hardness with the coming-up of bicarbonate-type and sulfate-type groundwater.It is no doubt that the buried depth of superficial water would get ever more deepened with time going on,which will have reached 19.92 meters by 2010 with the current annual average exploitation quantity increasing to 187.78 m3 in 2010.

39q6lqVG.title: The dynamics of wetland landscape pattern of qinhuangdao city
39q6lqVG.abstract: This paper explored the dynamics of the wetland landscape patterns of Qinhuangdao city from 1993 to 2008 on the GIS platform and based on the TM / ETM remote sensing image data source. The results showed that, during the year of 1993 to 2008, the wetland area has reduced by nearly 263 km2, among which, paddy field area reduced of 216 km2, accounting for 82% of the total reducing. This showed that the wetlands of Qinhuangdao city is mainly consisting of artificial wetlands, and because of the changing climate and the pressure of the water resources, the paddy field disappeared, which is the main factor that deciding the wetland. © 2013 IEEE.

2DVUBA3A.title: Spatio-temporal variability of groundwater level in China's Hebei plain
2DVUBA3A.abstract: Based on the spatially analytic function of GIS, the spatio-temporal variability of groundwater level in China's Hebei plain was studied by using the semivariogram and ordinary Kriging method of geostatistics, from which the spherical model fitted both the data sets in the periods 1986-1990 and 1996-2000. The spatial heterogeneity of groundwater level caused by its authigenic factors was big and, as an anisotropic result of groundwater level, it was found that there was a significant level difference in the period 1986-1990. The spatial distribution mapping of groundwater level by Kriging interpolation with the data of groundwater level in 1986-1990 and 1996-2000 showed that the trend of spatial distribution as a whole is that the groundwater level becomes high gradually from east to west and from the littoral plain to the piedmont plain, and the groundwater in the west middle plain is deeper than in the littoral plain. In conclusion, on the whole, there was a drawdown in the period from 1986 to 2000 because of such influencing factors as population, irrigation area, rainfall and run-off, which affects seriously the sustainable economic development of Hebei Province.

w21d5RYt.title: Study on spatial variability of groundwater in hebei plain
w21d5RYt.abstract: Groundwater resource is the main source of water supply in Hebei plain. But the continual reduction of groundwater has great impact on the regional sustainable utilization of water resources and the development of agriculture. This paper studied the spatial structure and variation characteristics of 5 factors of groundwater, such as chloride ion (CI), groundwater level (GL), nitrate nitrogen (NN), sulfate (S) and total hardness (TH), by the geostatistics method on the platform of GIS. The results showed that, (1) the spatial heterogeneity of nitrate nitrogen (NN) is mainly in small scale and of groundwater level (GL) are mainly in large scale. The spatial heterogeneity of other three factors is both reflected in small and large scale, (2) From the point of spatial distribution of groundwater level, the groundwater level is deepened from east to west, from the coastal plain to the piedmont plain and three great funnels of groundwater level were formed around the Shijiazhuang city, Xingtai city and Hand an city, (3) From the point of spatial distribution of groundwater quality, the high-value areas of chloride ion, sulfate and total hardness is distributed in the eastern and central, low-value distributed in the west. But the distribution of nitrate nitrogen is opposite, (4) in total, the distribution characteristics of the five groundwater indices were greatly impacted by the human activities. © 2013 IEEE.

yyBL5vtF.title: Analysis on geo-info-spectrum of landscape pattern evolvement of Qinhuangdao city
yyBL5vtF.abstract: The temporal and spatial change of landscape pattern in Qinhuangdao city since the early 1990s was analyzed based on RS and GIS survey. The land use information was acquired by interpreting the TM image data of 1993, 2000 and 2008, and 6 landscape indices (the proportion of all patches (PP), average patch area (APA), average patch perimeter (APP), average perimeter-area ration (APAR), fractal dimension (FD) and aggregation index (AI)) were adopted to characterize the spatial pattern of landscape during these three periods. The transition matrix was used to analyze the varying characteristics of all landscape types. The result showed that, natural and semi-natural landscape types, such as forest, grass and water body, decreased, so did agriculture land, however, the dry-land increased because of the decreasing irrigated land. The increased land for construction because of the human's activities, such as construction of cities and roads, is shown to be the main driving force for the changing landscape pattern.

9VxEUNA5.title: Evolving Analysis of Groundwater Environment in Hebei Plain
9VxEUNA5.abstract: The Hebei plain is the area,which water resource is one of the most absent at present in China.As the primary water supply source,the groundwater resource became the important factor that sustains the sustainable development of Hebei plain.This paper analyzed the evolving condition of groundwater environment in Hebei plain,confirmed that both nature and human being resulted in the change of the hydrogeological condition,the level and the water quality of groundwater in Hebei plain,which triggered off environment geological hazard including the land subsidence and the quality descent of groundwater.
keywords: Hebei Plain Groundwater Environment Evolving Analysis Land Subsidence

lyIufN59.title: OBJECT-ORIENTED IMAGE ANALYSIS METHOD FOR ESTUARINE TIDAL FLAT ACCRETION AND EROSION STUDY
lyIufN59.abstract: The shorelines of tidal flat in an estuary,located in the intersection zone of river and sea and in- fluenced by run-off water together with sediments from upstream,wave and current,tidal dynamics and hu- man activities,vary continuously in time and space.In overcoming some shortcomings existing in visual in- terpretation of shoreline from remote sensing images,this article elaborates an object-oriented shoreline au- tomatic extraction method.Taking east tidal flat region of Chongming Island(Dongtan)as an experimental area,four scenes of TM/ETM+ images acquired respectively on Dec 4 1990,April 4 1995,June 14 2000 and Nov 27 2005 covering Chongmin Dongtan are processed based on the object-oriented method.The shore- lines and polygons representing the tidal flat above shorelines are extracted for each year.The overlay anal- ysis is applied to observe the spatial variation of erosion and accretion of Chongming Dongtan from 1990 to 2005.The application results prove that the object-oriented remote sensing image recognition method for shorelines and tidal flat erosion and accretion analysis is quick,easy to use and effective.
